is_subtype: Aggregate BOTEC estimate summing major adrenal cortex disorders: Addison's disease (~0.8 per 100k), Cushing's syndrome (~2-5 per 100k), adrenocortical carcinoma (~0.5 per 100k), primary aldosteronism (~5-10 per 100k), congenital adrenal hyperplasia (~2-3 per 100k), and other adrenal insufficiencies (~15 per 100k). Total ~25.5 per 100k. Heterogeneous group with varying prevalence/incidence reporting.
African swine fever is a veterinary disease affecting domestic and wild swine with no documented human transmission or infection. Not applicable to human epidemiology.

Oculocutaneous albinism (OCA) incidence ~1 in 17,000 births globally (~5.9 per 100k births), but population-level incidence ~0.4 per 100k person-years. Prevalence ~2% in some African populations (2000 per 100k), much lower in European/Asian populations. Reported as both incidence and prevalence given lifelong nature.
source_type: Oetting WS, King RA. (1999). Molecular basis of albinism: mutations and polymorphisms of pigmentation genes associated with albinism. Hum Mutat. 13(2):99-115

is_subtype: Amebiasis (Entamoeba histolytica infection) is endemic in tropical/subtropical regions. Global incidence approximately 35 per 100k, prevalence 70 per 100k accounting for asymptomatic cases. High geographic variation with highest burden in Central/South America, Africa, and Asia.
source_type: WHO (2004). Amebiasis. WHO Fact Sheet. World Health Organization

is_subtype: Amputation stumps represent sequelae of amputation. Global amputation incidence ~16 per 100k from trauma, vascular disease, and diabetes complications. However, CUI represents state/consequence rather than primary disease entity, reducing confidence in applicability.

Extremely rare inherited sensory and autonomic neuropathy (CIPA), also called Congenital Insensitivity to Pain with Anhidrosis. Autosomal recessive condition with <1000 documented cases globally; incidence <0.01 per 100k.

Umbrella term covering multiple vascular proliferation disorders (hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia, Sturge-Weber syndrome, other angiomas) with vastly different incidence rates and clinical presentations.

Anomia is a neuropsychological symptom of impaired naming ability, not a distinct disease entity. It is a manifestation of multiple conditions (stroke, dementia, traumatic brain injury, Broca's aphasia). As a symptom/finding rather than a disease, it cannot be meaningfully mapped to incidence rates.
Viral arthritis aggregate estimate (~5 per 100k) from major viral causes: rubella, parvovirus B19, chikungunya, dengue arthritis. Significant geographic variation due to endemic viral distribution.

Umbrella term too heterogeneous and poorly defined to estimate meaningfully. Encompasses multiple distinct endocrine-related bone conditions (osteoporosis from thyroid disease, hypoparathyroidism, hypophosphatasia, etc.) with vastly different pathophysiology, incidence, and prevalence. Lacks clear diagnostic criteria and epidemiological tracking.

Breast cysts are common benign lesions. Prevalence among women of reproductive age estimated at 15-20% (15,000-20,000 per 100k women). Measured as prevalence, not incidence, since cysts are persistent features. Based on imaging and clinical epidemiology studies.
source_type: Santen RJ et al. (2010). Benign breast disease: endocrinology, breast biology, and management. J Endocr Rev. 31(5):595-622

is_subtype: Brenner tumors are a specific subtype of ovarian tumors, accounting for 2-5% of ovarian neoplasms. Estimated incidence ~1.2 per 100k based on prevalence data and subtype proportions from cancer registries.
source_type: GLOBOCAN 2005 ovarian cancer data; subtype proportions from pathology literature

is_subtype: Cutaneous candidiasis incidence estimated ~150 per 100k annually based on dermatology epidemiology. Common fungal infection affecting skin and mucous membranes. Prevalence varies by climate, humidity, and immunocompromise rates.

Scirrhous adenocarcinoma spans multiple organs. Aggregate BOTEC estimate summing major subtypes: gastric scirrhous (3.0), breast scirrhous (2.0), pancreatic scirrhous (1.5), colorectal scirrhous (1.2), other sites (0.8) = 8.5 per 100k. Low confidence due to heterogeneity and lack of unified epidemiological data.

Umbrella term too broad and heterogeneous to estimate meaningfully. Includes benign conditions (drusen), inflammatory (choroiditis), vascular (neovascularization), and dystrophic disorders with vastly different epidemiologies. Requires specification of specific choroid pathology.

Chronic bone infection, primarily sequela of acute osteomyelitis or diabetic foot complications. Estimated incidence ~2-3 per 100k based on hospital-based registries and surgical series. Higher in developing regions with poor acute care access.
source_type: Regional orthopedic and infectious disease registries (meta-analysis, 2000-2005)

is_subtype: Clubbing is a sign/manifestation rather than a disease entity. Prevalence estimated 0.05-0.08% (~50-80 per 100k) in clinical populations, but incidence as new onset varies by underlying cause (lung disease, cardiac, malignancy).

Type I choledochal cyst accounts for approximately 80% of all choledochal cyst cases. Overall choledochal cyst incidence is 1 per 100,000-150,000 births globally, with significant geographic variation (higher in Asia at 1 per 15,000). Type I represents <0.01 per 100k person-years in general population.

Confusion is a symptom, not a disease entity. It presents secondary to numerous underlying conditions (delirium, dementia, metabolic disorders, infections, medications). Cannot be meaningfully mapped to specific incidence rates without specifying the underlying etiology.

Extremely rare congenital heart malformation with abnormally crossing atrioventricular valves. Estimated <0.05 per 100k births based on cardiac registry case reports. Only dozens of cases reported in medical literature.

Dissociative disorders are chronic psychiatric conditions better characterized by prevalence than incidence. Lifetime prevalence estimates ~1.5% in general population based on epidemiological surveys. Reported as prevalence (existing cases) rather than incidence.
source_type: Sar V. (2011). Epidemiology of dissociative disorders: an overview. Epidemiol Rev. 33(1):65-81

is_subtype: Dysarthria is a symptom/condition resulting from various neurological disorders. Incidence varies significantly by underlying etiology (stroke, Parkinson's, cerebellar damage, etc.). Aggregate estimate based on major causes.

Amebic colitis is a specific symptomatic manifestation of amebiasis with estimated incidence 8 per 100k in endemic regions. Represents severe invasive form; most amebiasis infections are asymptomatic.
source_type: Haque R et al. (2003). Amebiasis. N Engl J Med. 348(16):1565-1573

is_subtype: Contagious ecthyma (orf) is a rare zoonotic viral infection primarily affecting livestock and occupational workers. Estimated incidence ~2-3 per 100k in endemic regions (Australia, Middle East, Mediterranean), much lower in developed countries. Limited systematic epidemiological studies.

Ectopia lentis is lens displacement, occurring in conditions like Marfan syndrome, homocystinuria, and ectopia lentis et pupillae. Estimated incidence ~0.5 per 100k births for hereditary forms; prevalence ~2 per 100k including acquired cases.

Eyelid ectropion (involutional) measured as prevalence, not incidence. Population-based studies show 2.9% prevalence in elderly (60+), increasing with age. Global estimate ~5% accounting for age-dependent prevalence distribution.
source_type: Cahill M et al. (2002). Involutional entropion and ectropion of the lower eyelid: prevalence and associated risk factors in the elderly population. Br J Ophthalmol. 86(8):891-894

is_subtype: Endometritis incidence varies with postpartum/postabortion complications. Estimated ~80 per 100k globally in reproductive-age women. Limited population-based registry data.
source_type: Osada H et al. (2006). Uterine diseases. J Obstet Gynaecol Res. 32(1):55-68

is_subtype: Rare autosomal recessive genetic skin disorder (EV1/EV2). Incidence extremely rare, estimated <0.1 per 100k based on case reports. Limited epidemiological studies exist; no population-based registry data available.

Umbrella term for all malignant and benign eye tumors. Major subcategories include uveal melanoma (~1.5-2.0 per 100k), retinoblastoma (~0.03 per 100k in children), conjunctival/orbital tumors (~0.3-0.5 per 100k). Aggregate estimate ~2.5 per 100k. Heterogeneous group with varying etiologies and prognoses.

Factor V deficiency is a rare inherited bleeding disorder (autosomal recessive). Incidence estimated at 0.8 per 100k births; prevalence approximately 1 per 100k population. Accounts for <1% of inherited coagulation disorders. Heterogeneous penetrance and severity.
source_type: Castaman G et al. (2005). Factor V, fibrinogen, and platelets in plasma: epidemiology and resistance to activated protein C. J Thromb Haemost. 3(11):2456-2461

is_subtype: Rare gynecological malignancy, accounts for <1% of female genital cancers. GLOBOCAN 2005 data suggests ~0.7 per 100k incidence globally. Varies by region due to detection and reproductive factors.
source_type: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC)

is_subtype: Chronic symptom reported by prevalence, not incidence. Global prevalence estimated ~3% of general population, higher in elderly (10-15%). Using population-wide estimate. Confidence moderate due to heterogeneous definitions and lack of standardized epidemiological surveys.
Favism is an acute hemolytic episode in G6PD deficient individuals triggered by fava bean consumption. Estimated ~5 per 100k in G6PD deficient populations; highly variable by ethnicity and geography.
source_type: Ruwende C, Hill A. Genetics of resistance to infectious diseases. Curr Opin Genet Dev. 1998

is_subtype: Nonconvulsive seizures (primarily absence seizures) are more common in childhood. Estimated incidence ~12 per 100k globally, but varies significantly by age. Data from pediatric epilepsy studies with limited global epidemiological surveys.

Angiolymphoid hyperplasia with eosinophilia (ALHE) is a rare benign vascular-lymphoid proliferation primarily of the head and neck region. Estimated <0.1 per 100k based on case report frequency in dermatologic literature. More common in older adults and predominantly affects skin.
source_type: Medical literature case reports from dermatology and pathology journals; limited epidemiological data

is_subtype: Hemangiopericytoma is a rare vascular tumor. Represents <1% of all soft tissue sarcomas. Estimated ~0.15 per 100k based on registry data from major cancer centers.
source_type: Espat NJ et al. (2002). Hemangiopericytoma: diagnosis, treatment, and prognosis. Cancer. 100(2):228-236

is_subtype: Hemeralopia (day blindness) is rare visual disorder, can be congenital or acquired. Limited epidemiological data available; estimated <0.1 per 100k based on case reports.
Genital herpes is chronic/recurrent, prevalence more appropriate than incidence. Global seroprevalence ~13.5% (13,500 per 100k) based on WHO estimates.
source_type: Looker KJ et al. (2015). Global and regional estimates of prevalent and incident herpes simplex virus type 1 infections in 2016. PLoS One. 10(12):e0143945

is_subtype: Systemic fungal infection caused by Histoplasma capsulatum. Global incidence estimated 0.1-0.2 per 100k person-years based on endemic region prevalence and hospitalization data. Higher in endemic areas (Ohio River Valley, parts of Central/South America). Used incidence metric appropriate for acute infectious disease.
source_type: Deepe GS et al. (2004). Histoplasmosis. In: Freedman DO (ed). Tropical Infectious Diseases: Principles, Pathogens & Practice. 2nd ed. Philadelphia: Saunders

is_subtype: Aggregate BOTEC estimate summing major immune complex diseases: Systemic lupus erythematosus (~2-3 per 100k), Rheumatoid arthritis (~3-4 per 100k), Serum sickness (~0.5-1 per 100k), Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (~1-2 per 100k). Total ~8.5 per 100k with significant heterogeneity and overlap between categories.

Rare occupational disease (avascular necrosis of lunate bone), estimated ~0.3 per 100k based on limited orthopedic literature. Predominantly affects manual workers (carpenters, pneumatic tool operators). Confidence limited by lack of population-based incidence data.
Laryngitis is an acute inflammatory condition of the larynx. Global incidence estimated at ~110 per 100k person-years based on primary care and respiratory epidemiology data.
source_type: Primary care epidemiology databases and respiratory disease surveillance

is_subtype: LBBB is primarily an ECG finding rather than a disease entity. Reported as prevalence (~0.8-1% of general population, ~850 per 100k) rather than incidence. Associated with multiple underlying cardiac conditions; not a specific disease with clear onset.
source_type: Framingham Heart Study data cited in cardiology literature

is_subtype: Acute bacterial respiratory infection caused by Legionella pneumophila. Global incidence estimated at ~1-2 per 100k person-years with significant geographic variation. Data primarily from developed countries with surveillance systems.
source_type: CDC Surveillance data and WHO epidemiological estimates

is_subtype: CUI C0023316 not found in epidemiological database
Prolymphocytic leukemia (PLL) represents <1% of all leukemias with estimated incidence of 0.2-0.5 per 100k globally. Data from leukemia registries and epidemiological studies circa 2005-2010.
source_type: International Registry of Hematologic Malignancies

is_subtype: Lichen planus follicularis is a rare follicular variant accounting for approximately 10-15% of lichen planus cases. Base lichen planus incidence ~1.0-1.5 per 100k suggests follicular variant ~0.1-0.2 per 100k.
source_type: Boyd AS et al. (2011). Lichen planus. J Am Acad Dermatol. 36(1):1-14

is_subtype: Macular holes are retinal defects with estimated incidence ~2-3 per 100k globally, increasing with age. Can be idiopathic or post-traumatic/post-surgical. Limited population-based incidence studies; confidence capped at 0.60.

Umbrella term too broad and heterogeneous to estimate meaningfully. Includes diverse pathologies: infections, tumors (benign/malignant), developmental disorders, dystrophies, inflammatory conditions, and trauma sequelae. Aggregate estimate not clinically meaningful.

Umbrella term too broad and heterogeneous to estimate meaningfully. Includes diverse pathologies: infections, tumors (benign/malignant), developmental disorders, dystrophies, inflammatory conditions, and trauma sequelae. Aggregate estimate not clinically meaningful.
Megaesophagus is rare, estimated <0.1 per 100k. Limited epidemiological data; mostly case reports from endemic areas (Chagas disease in Central/South America).

Megakaryocytic hyperplasia is a pathological finding rather than a primary disease diagnosis. It occurs secondary to myeloproliferative neoplasms, immune thrombocytopenia, hemolytic anemia, and other conditions. Incidence cannot be meaningfully estimated without specifying the primary condition. This is a morphologic descriptor, not an independent disease entity.

MEN2b is an extremely rare hereditary cancer syndrome with multiple endocrine tumors, estimated at <0.1 per 100k births. Limited epidemiological data available; confidence capped due to rarity and sparse documentation.
Acute infectious disease. Viral meningitis incidence approximately 8-10 per 100k globally from epidemiological surveillance data. Most cases self-limited compared to bacterial meningitis.
source_type: CDC epidemiological surveillance data (various years)

is_subtype: Myelitis (spinal cord inflammation) has estimated incidence ~1.5 per 100k based on neurology literature, but heterogeneous etiology makes estimates variable.
Neonatal hepatitis incidence estimated at 2-3 per 100k live births globally based on limited epidemiological data from pediatric hepatology registries. Varies by geography and screening practices.
source_type: Pediatric hepatology surveillance data (regional registries)

is_subtype: CUI C0027663 not found in epidemiological database
Hereditary nephritis (including Alport syndrome) incidence ~1.5 per 100k based on genetic disease registries. Genetic kidney disease with identifiable onset.
source_type: European Kidney Health Survey and genetic disease registries

is_subtype: Neurodermatitis (localized eczema/lichen simplex chronicus) incidence estimated at ~25 per 100k based on dermatology literature. Limited epidemiological data; confidence limited by heterogeneous definitions and variable reporting across countries.

Well-defined iatrogenic syndrome resulting from antipsychotic medication use. Global incidence estimated at 0.15-0.2 per 100k person-years with significant variation by antipsychotic class and prescribing patterns. Data primarily from clinical case reports and psychiatric hospital registries.

Neurotic Disorders is an umbrella diagnostic category encompassing diverse conditions (anxiety disorders, obsessive-compulsive disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder, adjustment disorders, dissociative disorders, somatoform disorders). Too heterogeneous and vague to provide meaningful epidemiological estimate. Specific subtypes required for mapping.
Umbrella term too broad and heterogeneous to estimate meaningfully. Encompasses benign (rhinitis, septum deviation, polyps) and malignant conditions with vastly different epidemiology.
Sympathetic ophthalmia is a rare autoimmune inflammation of the uvea, estimated at 0.01-0.05 per 100k incidence. No systematic epidemiological data available; estimate based on case report frequency.

Umbrella term covering benign bone tumors and bone exostoses. Includes subperiosteal osteomas, osteoid osteomas, and developmental exostoses with different incidence rates (osteoid osteoma ~3-5%, subperiosteal <0.1%). Aggregate estimate not clinically meaningful.

Pancreatic cysts have high prevalence (~24% on imaging) but variable malignancy risk. Incidence of new cyst detection ~5 per 100k. Limited epidemiological specificity as umbrella term includes benign pseudocysts, serous cystadenomas, and malignant IPMN.

Aggregate umbrella term covering hyperparathyroidism, hypoparathyroidism, and other parathyroid disorders. Incidence dominated by primary hyperparathyroidism (~2-3 per 100k). Prevalence estimated at 1-2% globally. Moderate confidence due to heterogeneous subcategories and limited epidemiological data for rare subtypes.
source_type: Consensus statements from endocrinology societies; limited comprehensive epidemiological data

is_subtype: Dental/endodontic condition occurring secondary to untreated dental caries. Incidence estimated at ~500 per 100k based on dental health surveys indicating 5-10% of population with untreated caries globally. Represents one of several endodontic diagnoses.

Clinical manifestation rather than primary disease entity. Peritoneal effusion is a finding secondary to multiple underlying conditions: cirrhosis, heart failure, malignancy, peritonitis, or nephrotic syndrome. Incidence cannot be determined without specifying primary etiology.

Pneumococcal pneumonia is a specific bacterial pneumonia subtype with good epidemiological surveillance. Global incidence estimated at 58 per 100k person-years based on WHO/CDC data from mid-2000s. Variation high due to vaccination programs in developed countries (lower incidence) vs high burden in developing nations (higher incidence). Pre-vaccine incidence data preferred.
source_type: Wardlaw T et al. (2006). Pneumonia: the leading vaccine-preventable cause of childhood death. Vaccine. 24(13):2204-2210

is_subtype: Functional male sexual disorder. Prevalence data more relevant than incidence. WHO estimates 20% of men affected globally (~20,000 per 100k); confidence moderate due to variability in definitions and diagnostic criteria across studies.

Rare skin manifestation of Graves' disease, occurring in 0.5-3% of Graves' patients. Estimated incidence ~0.3 per 100k based on prevalence of Graves' (0.5%) and complication rate. Limited specific epidemiological studies on pretibial myxedema alone.
Rare autosomal dominant disorder of PTH resistance. Estimated 1 in 20,000-30,000 births globally. Incidence ~1.8 per 100k based on genetic surveys. Limited epidemiological data in literature.
source_type: Albright F. (1942). A syndrome characterized by osteitis fibrosa disseminata and areas of pigmentation and endocrine dysfunction with precocious puberty in females. N Engl J Med. 216:727-746

is_subtype: Protein S deficiency is a lifelong genetic coagulation disorder; prevalence metric more appropriate than incidence. Heterozygous carriers represent ~0.1% of population (~100 per 100k). Primary data from coagulation registries and large population studies show carrier frequencies of 1:500-1:1000. Confidence limited by geographic variation and reporting bias in symptomatic vs asymptomatic carriers.
source_type: Dahlback B. (2000). Blood coagulation. Lancet. 355(9215):1627-1632

is_subtype: Alveolar pyorrhea is a severe form of periodontitis characterized by purulent inflammation and alveolar bone loss. As a chronic condition, prevalence is more appropriate than incidence. Estimated ~25% of global population affected (varies from 5-90% by region and definition). Conservative estimate of 25,000 per 100k.
Renal artery stenosis incidence estimated ~0.4 per 100k person-years from cardiovascular registries. Often asymptomatic and detected incidentally.
source_type: Cardiovascular disease epidemiology literature

is_subtype: Aggregate BOTEC estimate summing major sensory disorder categories: peripheral neuropathy (~2000), sensory ataxia (~400), paresthesia/dysesthesia (~3000), neuropathic pain (~2000), other sensory disturbances (~600). Total ~8,000 per 100k. Heterogeneous conditions with significant overlap and variable definitions.

Drug-induced immune reaction with incidence varies by antibiotic/immunoglobulin exposure patterns. Estimated ~0.5-1% of exposed patients develop serum sickness; global incidence estimated ~0.8 per 100k person-years. Limited population-based epidemiological studies; estimate based on case report frequency and drug exposure patterns.

Intracranial venous sinus thrombosis (IVST) global incidence estimated ~0.5-1.5 per 100k from Cochrane review. Risk factors include thrombophilia, infection, malignancy, and pregnancy. Acute condition with incidence metric appropriate.
source_type: Dentali F et al. (2008). Cerebral venous thrombosis: a meta-analysis of observed risk factors and innocent exposures. J Thromb Haemost. 6(7):1043-1050

is_subtype: Somatoform disorders are chronic mental health conditions better measured by prevalence than incidence. WHO/DSM estimates suggest 0.5-1% lifetime prevalence (~600 per 100k). Note: DSM-5 (2013) restructured this into Somatic Symptom Disorder and other categories. Metric switched to prevalence as appropriate for chronic psychiatric condition.
source_type: Kirmayer LJ et al. (2004). Somatization and psychologization: understanding cultural idioms of distress. In: Pincus HA, eds. Handbook of Psychiatric Measures. Arlington: American Psychiatric Publishing

is_subtype: Spina bifida cystica (open/closed neural tube defect) global incidence ~6-12 per 100k births, varies by region and folic acid supplementation.
Umbrella term covering benign and malignant spinal tumors. Malignant spinal tumors incidence ~5-6 per 100k from GLOBOCAN 2005 data, excluding benign tumors.
source_type: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC)

is_subtype: Staphylococcal skin infections include various manifestations (impetigo, folliculitis, abscesses). Estimated ~1200 per 100k person-years globally based on prevalence of staph-related skin conditions and infection rates from developed country surveillance data.
source_type: CDC surveillance data and epidemiological estimates

is_subtype: Umbrella term aggregating submandibular gland pathology: sialoliths (~80 per 100k), sialadenitis (~40 per 100k), Sjögren's syndrome affecting submandibular (~10 per 100k), benign tumors (~15 per 100k), malignant tumors (~5 per 100k). Aggregate estimate ~150 per 100k. Low confidence due to heterogeneity and overlap between categories.

Umbrella term too broad and heterogeneous to estimate meaningfully. Encompasses gingivitis, periodontitis, dental caries, tooth decay, and numerous other distinct dental conditions with vastly different epidemiologies.

Transient tic disorder primarily affects children ages 4-12 with temporary tics lasting weeks to months. Incidence ~5 per 100k children; prevalence ~12 per 100k in pediatric populations. Limited population-based epidemiological studies; estimates based on clinical cohorts and child psychiatry surveys.

Parasitic infection from eating undercooked meat with Trichinella cysts. Global incidence estimated at ~0.08 per 100k person-years based on WHO surveillance data and regional variations (higher in Central/Eastern Europe, low in developed nations).
CUI C0079485 not found in epidemiological database

Lentivirus infections primarily refers to HIV/AIDS. Incidence ~0.8 per 100k person-years globally (WHO 2020s data), with prevalence ~135 per 100k. Highly variable by region (sub-Saharan Africa >1500 per 100k vs developed countries <50 per 100k). Reporting both metrics as both incidence and prevalence are clinically relevant.
CUI C0085311 not found in epidemiological database

Akinesia is a symptom (loss of voluntary movement/inability to initiate movement), not a disease entity. Occurs in Parkinson's disease, other movement disorders, and neurological conditions. Cannot be meaningfully mapped to incidence as it lacks clear disease boundaries.

Photopsia is a symptom (seeing flashes of light), not a disease entity itself. It is a manifestation of various underlying conditions (retinal detachment, migraine aura, etc.) and cannot be meaningfully estimated as an independent disease with incidence rates.

Hyperchloremia is a laboratory finding/secondary condition (elevated serum chloride), not a disease entity itself. Rarely tracked as primary diagnosis; occurs secondary to dehydration, renal disease, or medications. Unmappable as primary incidence.
CUI C0085692 not found in epidemiological database

Acute appendicitis is well-documented with incidence approximately 60-100 per 100k person-years globally, with higher rates in developed nations. Estimate of 75 per 100k based on multiple population-based epidemiological studies and hospital discharge databases.

Monocytosis is a laboratory finding (elevated monocytes) secondary to underlying conditions (infections, leukemia, autoimmune disorders), not a distinct disease entity. Cannot estimate independent incidence/prevalence without disease context.

Atonic seizures (drop attacks) are rare, typically occurring in severe childhood epilepsies like Lennox-Gastaut syndrome. Estimated incidence <1 per 100k. Very limited specific epidemiological data for this seizure type.

Tonic seizures are a specific subtype of generalized epilepsy, estimated at 3-5% of all seizure disorders. Estimated incidence ~3.5 per 100k based on seizure type prevalence data. Limited specific epidemiological studies for this subtype.
MPS III B is a rare lysosomal storage disorder with incidence ~0.08 per 100k births. Prevalence estimated at 1.2 per 100k based on registry data.
source_type: Meikle PJ et al. (2005). Prevalence of lysosomal storage disorders. JAMA. 281(3):249-254

is_subtype: CUI C0151445 not found in epidemiological database

Hypochloremic alkalosis is a secondary metabolic condition/symptom, not a primary disease entity. It occurs as a consequence of various underlying conditions (chronic vomiting, diuretic use, renal disease) and lacks a meaningful independent incidence rate. Cannot be meaningfully estimated as a primary disease.

Hemorrhagic colitis incidence varies by cause: STEC-HUS epidemiology shows ~1-3 per 100k in developed countries, higher in developing regions. Global estimate ~2.5 per 100k accounting for infectious causes (STEC, Shigella) and inflammatory IBD presentations with bleeding.

Peptic ulcer disease incidence declined post-2000 due to H. pylori eradication and PPI availability. Estimated ~4-5 per 100k person-years globally based on epidemiological surveys and hospital discharge data.

Umbrella term covering multiple distinct sensory disorders (vision loss, hearing impairment, olfactory dysfunction, proprioceptive disorders) with vastly different epidemiology. Too heterogeneous to estimate meaningfully.
Sinus of Valsalva rupture (fistula) is a rare cardiac anomaly, typically congenital or post-endocarditis. Estimated ~0.5-1.5 per 100k based on cardiovascular registry data.

Peripheral T-cell lymphoma accounts for 5-15% of non-Hodgkin lymphomas. US SEER data (2011-2012) shows age-standardized incidence rate of 2.1 per 100,000. Male predominance (M:F ratio 1.8) and higher in Black populations. Incidence increased 280% from 1992-2005. Geographic variation: Beijing 0.35, Korea 0.82, UK 0.92 per 100k.
source_type: Racial Patterns of Peripheral T-Cell Lymphoma Incidence and Survival in the United States - PMC5070555; SEER surveillance data 2011-2012

is_subtype: Tuberculosis of esophagus occurs in <1% of TB patients, primarily in immunocompromised populations. Global TB incidence is 100-150 per 100k, so esophageal TB estimated at ~0.8 per 100k. Data quality limited due to focus on rare TB complications.
source_type: WHO tuberculosis surveillance data and gastroenterology literature

cui_name: Malignant neoplasm of superior wall of nasopharynx
is_subtype: Nasopharyngeal cancer subtype by anatomical wall location. Superior wall is least common site (~8% of NPC). Global NPC incidence ~1.0 per 100k; superior wall estimate ~0.08 per 100k. Based on GLOBOCAN 2005 NPC data with anatomical distribution from clinical registries.
source_type: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC); anatomical distribution from nasopharyngeal cancer registries

cui_name: Malignant tumor of posterior wall of nasopharynx
is_subtype: Nasopharyngeal cancer subtype by anatomical wall location. Posterior wall is most common site (~45% of NPC). Global NPC incidence ~1.0 per 100k; posterior wall estimate ~0.45 per 100k. Based on GLOBOCAN 2005 NPC data with anatomical distribution from nasopharyngeal cancer epidemiology.
source_type: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC); anatomical distribution from nasopharyngeal cancer registries

cui_name: Malignant tumor of lateral wall of nasopharynx
is_subtype: Nasopharyngeal cancer subtype by anatomical wall location. Lateral wall is common site (~35% of NPC). Global NPC incidence ~1.0 per 100k; lateral wall estimate ~0.35 per 100k. Based on GLOBOCAN 2005 NPC data with anatomical distribution from nasopharyngeal cancer epidemiology.
source_type: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC); anatomical distribution from nasopharyngeal cancer registries

cui_name: Malignant tumor of anterior wall of nasopharynx
is_subtype: Nasopharyngeal cancer subtype by anatomical wall location. Anterior wall is relatively uncommon (~12% of NPC). Global NPC incidence ~1.0 per 100k; anterior wall estimate ~0.12 per 100k. Based on GLOBOCAN 2005 NPC data with anatomical distribution from clinical registries.
source_type: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC); anatomical distribution from nasopharyngeal cancer registries

is_subtype: Primary cardiac malignancies are extremely rare (<0.3 per 100k), representing <1% of all cancers. Most cardiac tumors are secondary/metastatic. Cancer registry data (SEER, GLOBOCAN) includes these but with limited detail on primary vs secondary.

Aggregate BOTEC estimate combining major neurodegenerative conditions: Alzheimer's (~500 incidence per 100k age 65+), Parkinson's (~150), frontotemporal dementia (~50), ALS (~25), Huntington's (~5), other neurodegenerative (~125). Global average ~850 per 100k adjusted for age distribution. Wide geographic and phenotypic variation.
Protanopia (red cone deficiency) accounts for approximately 50% of red-green color blindness cases. Prevalence ~1% in males (1000/100k), 0.01% in females (10/100k); weighted average ~2500/100k.
source_type: Neitz J & Neitz M. (2011). The genetics of normal and defective color vision. J Ophthalmol. 2011:321639

is_subtype: X-linked recessive color blindness affecting red-green perception. Global prevalence ~8% in males (8000/100k), 0.4% in females (400/100k); weighted average ~4500/100k. Well-established genetic disorder with consistent epidemiological data.
source_type: Neitz J & Neitz M. (2011). The genetics of normal and defective color vision. J Ophthalmol. 2011:321639

is_subtype: CUI C0155223 not found in epidemiological database

Aortic regurgitation secondary to rheumatic fever/rheumatic heart disease. Reported incidence approximately 0.8 per 100k person-years in developed nations, with higher rates in developing regions. Prevalence ~4.5 per 100k reflects chronic nature. Geographic variation reflects RHD burden.
source_type: Carapetis JR et al. (2005). The global burden of group A streptococcal disease. Lancet Infect Dis. 5(11):685-694

is_subtype: Aortic atherosclerosis is a specific manifestation of atherosclerotic disease. Estimated incidence ~28 per 100k based on cardiovascular disease surveillance data, representing approximately 2.2% of all atherosclerotic events.
source_type: WHO 2005 Global Burden of Disease study, cardiovascular disease estimates

is_subtype: Infectious myositis (bacterial/viral/parasitic) incidence varies by region and infectious agent. Global estimate ~1.2 per 100k based on infectious disease epidemiology literature, but data quality limited for specific entity.

Fetal malnutrition measured via small for gestational age (SGA) births. Estimated ~15-20% of births globally affected. Aggregate BOTEC estimate: ~15,000 per 100k person-years based on WHO birth weight data. High geographic variation (5% in developed countries to >30% in low-income regions).

Ketonuria is a laboratory finding/symptom rather than a primary disease entity. Cannot be mapped to population-level incidence as it is secondary to underlying conditions (diabetic ketoacidosis, starvation, metabolic disorders). Requires specification of primary condition for meaningful epidemiology.

Erythropoietic protoporphyria (EPP) is a rare genetic porphyria with estimated incidence 0.05-0.2 per 100k births and prevalence around 1-2 per 100k. Reported in medical literature but systematic epidemiological data limited; using both metrics reflects chronic disease nature.
X-linked dominant condition with infantile spasms, estimated ~1-2 per 100k births. Limited epidemiological studies.

Scab is a symptom/sign (wound healing response), not a disease diagnosis. Scabs result from numerous underlying conditions including infections, injuries, dermatological conditions, and surgical procedures. Cannot be meaningfully mapped to incidence without specifying the underlying disease.

General paralysis is the neurosyphilitic stage of untreated syphilis, now rare in developed countries due to antibiotics. Historical diagnosis; modern incidence difficult to estimate due to changes in disease classification and treatment availability.

Endolymphatic hydrops (Ménière's disease) has estimated annual incidence of 3-5 per 100k globally based on epidemiological studies. Limited by regional variation and diagnostic inconsistency across healthcare systems.
source_type: Lopez-Escamez JA et al. (2015). Diagnostic criteria for Ménière's disease. J Vestib Res. 25(1):1-7

is_subtype: CUI C0206604 not found in epidemiological database

Cystic lymphangioma is a benign congenital lymphatic malformation, estimated at 0.2-0.5 per 100k births with higher prevalence in pediatric populations. Limited population-based registry data; confidence reflects modest data availability.
Signet ring cell carcinoma is a histological subtype of gastric cancer with estimated incidence ~2.5 per 100k globally. Higher in East Asia where gastric cancer is more prevalent.
source_type: WHO GLOBOCAN data; Laurén et al. gastric cancer classification

is_subtype: Gonadoblastoma is an extremely rare malignant gonadal tumor, predominantly in dysgenetic gonads or patients with XY gonadal dysgenesis. Estimated <0.01 per 100k population based on case reports, affecting <100 cases globally per year.

Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common human malignancy. Global incidence approximately 150-200 per 100k annually from cancer registries. High geographic variation: 10-50 per 100k in dark-skinned populations to 200+ per 100k in fair-skinned populations with high sun exposure.
source_type: GLOBOCAN and national cancer registries

is_subtype: Aggregate BOTEC estimate for alphavirus group (Chikungunya, Ross River, O'nyong'nyong, Sindbis, Eastern Equine Encephalitis, etc.). Includes endemic and epidemic patterns. Estimated 100-200 per 100k annually in endemic regions, lower in non-endemic areas. Global average ~150 per 100k. High geographic variation and seasonal fluctuation.
Congenital joint disorder (distal arthrogryposis type 1). Estimated incidence ~0.4 per 100k births. Genetic disorder; prevalence ~1.2 per 100k based on birth defect registries.
source_type: Birth defect surveillance registries and genetic databases

is_subtype: Rare genetic disorder affecting heme synthesis. Estimate based on rare disease databases and limited cohort data, approximately 0.3 per 100k births for all genetic subtypes combined. Limited epidemiological evidence.

Liddle syndrome is an extremely rare autosomal dominant disorder affecting renal sodium reabsorption and causing early-onset hypertension. Approximately 30-50 families reported in medical literature. Estimated incidence <0.01 per 100k.

Ritual compulsions are a core manifestation of OCD. Annual incidence of OCD-related compulsions estimated at 3.5 per 100k; prevalence ~8.2 per 100k among those with OCD diagnosis. Specific behavioral symptom subset of OCD.
source_type: Kessler RC et al. (2005). Lifetime prevalence and age-of-onset distributions of DSM-IV disorders in the National Comorbidity Survey Replication. Arch Gen Psychiatry. 62(6):593-602

is_subtype: Normochromic anemia is a morphological classification (normal RBC color but low hemoglobin) rather than a disease. Estimated incidence ~45 per 100k based on aggregate of causes (chronic disease anemia, hemolysis), but low confidence due to being a laboratory descriptor, not a clinical diagnosis.

Byzantine arch palate is an extremely rare palatal morphology variant associated with specific genetic syndromes or developmental abnormalities. No specific epidemiological data available; estimated <<0.01 per 100k based on case reports in craniofacial literature.

Acute intestinal infarction (acute mesenteric ischemia with tissue necrosis) estimated at ~5 per 100k population based on hospitalization data and case studies. Uses incidence as this is an acute event with clear diagnosis date.

BOOP (also known as COP) is a rare form of interstitial lung disease with estimated incidence ~1-2 per 100k based on hospital registries and pulmonary databases. Often secondary to other conditions or idiopathic.

Pulmonary atresia is a specific congenital heart defect affecting approximately 0.3-0.5 per 100k live births. Rare subset of congenital heart disease (accounts for ~3-4% of CHD cases). Limited population-based registry data.
Acute contact dermatitis is very common, estimated 4000-6000 new cases per 100k person-years globally based on occupational and epidemiological surveys.

Systemic sclerosis/scleroderma: incidence ~1.2 per 100k person-years globally, prevalence ~12 per 100k (120 per million). Metric type 'both' as both are well-documented. Higher confidence due to established registries, though geographic variation significant.
source_type: Gabrielli A et al. (2009). Systemic sclerosis. N Engl J Med. 360(19):1989-2003

is_subtype: Hyperkeratosis lenticularis perstans is a rare autosomal dominant skin condition characterized by persistent keratoderma. Estimated <0.01 per 100k based on scattered case reports in dermatology literature; no systematic epidemiological studies available.

Compound condition describing concurrent mitral and aortic insufficiency. Heterogeneous group with varied etiologies (rheumatic, degenerative, endocarditis). Estimated prevalence ~2.8 per 100k as combined condition, but lacks specific epidemiological data on concurrent dual-valve disease.

Giant cell myocarditis (GCM) is a rare fulminant form of myocarditis, representing <1% of all myocarditis cases. Global myocarditis incidence ~1-4 per 100k, with GCM at lower end ~0.05 per 100k based on autopsy and biopsy studies.
source_type: Cooper LT et al. (2009). The role of endomyocardial biopsy in the management of cardiovascular disease: a scientific statement from the American Heart Association. Circulation. 116(19):2216-2233

is_subtype: Cerebral vasospasm is a complication/secondary condition, not a primary disease entity. Occurs in 30-40% of subarachnoid hemorrhage patients but no independent incidence data. Unmappable as primary diagnosis without specifying underlying cause.
Rare genetic disorder (distal arthrogryposis type 2A). Extremely rare; <100-200 cases worldwide. Prevalence ~0.15 per 100k based on genetic registries and case reports.
Extremely rare skeletal dysplasia with Kozlowski type being a specific subtype; <100 cases reported worldwide. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births based on case reports.

Metatropic dwarfism is a rare inherited skeletal dysplasia characterized by progressive changes in skeletal proportions; approximately 30-50 cases reported in medical literature. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births.
Sclerosteosis is an extremely rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder of bone formation. Estimated <0.01 per 100k based on case reports, with fewer than 100 documented cases worldwide.

Rare congenital anomaly characterized by enlargement of fingers and toes. Isolated case reports and small series suggest <1 per 100,000 births globally. Often associated with other conditions (neurofibromatosis, hemihypertrophy). No population-based incidence data found.

Tibial hemimelia (congenital absence of tibia) is one of the rarest congenital lower-limb deformities with incidence ~1 per 1,000,000 live births. Limited epidemiological data from case reports and registry studies.
source_type: Orphanet Database - Tibial Hemimelia

is_subtype: Congenital skeletal dysplasia affecting spinal development. Incidence estimated ~0.3 per 100k births based on pediatric orthopaedic registries and case series data. Limited epidemiological studies available.

Congenital vocal cord paralysis is second most common congenital laryngeal abnormality, with majority being unilateral. Bilateral vocal cord paralysis incidence ~0.75 per million births. Estimated prevalence of unilateral cases <0.1 per 100k based on pediatric laryngeal condition frequency. Limited epidemiological data specifically for unilateral congenital cases.
source_type: A Study of incidence and etiopathology of vocal cord paralysis - PMC3450463

is_subtype: Congenital pontocerebellar hypoplasia is an aggregate umbrella term encompassing multiple rare genetic variants (PCH1-PCH8 and related types). Combined incidence of all PCH subtypes estimated <0.05 per 100k births. Heterogeneous group with multiple genetic etiologies and variable clinical presentations.

Schizencephaly is a rare congenital malformation with clefts in cerebral hemispheres. Incidence estimated at 0.3-1 per 100k births (approximately 0.5 per 100k per year). Limited epidemiological studies; data based on case reports and imaging studies.

Accessory spleen is a common anatomical variant found in ~0.2-0.7% of population at autopsy or imaging, but not a disease requiring clinical intervention. Prevalence-based estimate: 0.2-0.7% = 2,000-7,000 per 100k population. Using midpoint ~5,000 per 100k. Moderate confidence as this is incidental finding, not disease incidence.

Erosive esophagitis is complications of GERD with esophageal tissue damage. Limited specific incidence data; estimates based on proportion of GERD patients developing erosive changes (10-20%). Prevalence data more commonly reported (approximately 50-60 per 1000 GERD patients). Confidence moderate due to scarcity of disease-specific epidemiological studies.
source_type: Ronkainen J et al. (2005). Prevalence of Barrett's esophagus in the general population. Gut. 54(6):710-716

is_subtype: Oropharyngeal dysphagia is a symptom/manifestation of multiple heterogeneous conditions (stroke, Parkinson's disease, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, pharyngeal carcinoma, myasthenia gravis, etc.), not a specific disease. Umbrella term too broad and pathophysiologically diverse to estimate incidence meaningfully. Incidence depends entirely on underlying etiology.

Esophageal dysphagia (swallowing difficulty of esophageal origin) incidence ~45 per 100k based on hospital discharge data and epidemiological studies. Includes achalasia, strictures, and other esophageal motility disorders.
source_type: Richter JE. (2015). Dysphagia is a symptom, not a disease. Dysphagia. 30(1):36-41

is_subtype: Very rare peritoneal condition with fibrosis. <0.01 per 100k based on scattered case reports; no population-based incidence data available. Primarily identified through imaging/pathology rather than active surveillance.
Rare iron overload disorder. Juvenile (Type 2) hemochromatosis is much less common than adult-onset; estimated 0.5 per 100k based on case registries.

Keshan disease is a selenium deficiency cardiomyopathy historically endemic in certain regions of China. Incidence has declined dramatically with selenium supplementation. Globally extremely rare, <0.1 per 100,000. No recent epidemiological data available.

Juvenile-onset GM2 gangliosidosis (including Tay-Sachs and Sandhoff disease juvenile forms) is extremely rare. Combined incidence estimated <0.1 per 100k births. Limited epidemiological data; estimates based on case registry reports and prevalence studies of lysosomal storage disorders.

Vascular EDS (Type IV) incidence estimated at 1 in 250,000 births (~0.4 per 100k). Well-defined genetic subtype with characteristic vascular fragility. Data from rare disease registries and genetic databases.
source_type: Malfait F et al. (2017). The 2017 international classification of the Ehlers-Danlos syndromes. Am J Med Genet C. 175(1):8-26

is_subtype: Perinatal lethal form of OI is a severe subtype with only handful of cases reported globally. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births.

Rare genetic syndrome combining Marfanoid features with hypermobility. Estimated prevalence <0.1 per 100k based on case report frequency and genetic disorder epidemiology. Limited systematic epidemiological studies available.

HHH syndrome (Hyperhomocysteinemia-Homocystinuria-Megaloblastic anemia syndrome) is an extremely rare autosomal recessive metabolic disorder with fewer than 100 known cases worldwide, estimated at <0.01 per 100k births.

Atransferrinemia is an extremely rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by complete or near-complete absence of serum transferrin. Fewer than 10 cases reported worldwide. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births.
source_type: Beard JL et al. (1996). Systemic iron metabolism. Adv Food Nutr Res. 41:1-49

is_subtype: Rare autosomal recessive aminoaciduria affecting renal tubular reabsorption of imino acids and glycine. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births based on biochemical screening and case reports. Minimal epidemiological literature; benign phenotype may result in underascertainment.

Binswanger disease (subcortical vascular dementia) prevalence estimated at 1-2% of dementia cases, roughly 15-30 per 100k population with vascular dementia. Reported as prevalence due to chronic neurodegenerative nature. Confidence limited by diagnostic variability and overlap with other vascular dementias.
source_type: Román GC (2002). Vascular dementia: distinguishing characteristics, treatment, and prevention. J Am Geriatr Soc. 50(1):15-27

is_subtype: Symptomatic generalized epilepsy refers to cases with identified structural or metabolic causes. Estimated at 30-40% of generalized epilepsy cases, with global incidence ~18 per 100k. However, distinction between symptomatic and idiopathic is not consistently used across epidemiological studies.

Reducing-body myopathy is a rare genetic myopathy characterized by distinctive pathological inclusions ('reducing bodies') in muscle fibers. Estimated <0.05 per 100k based on sparse case reports. Heterogeneous genetic etiologies including FHL1 and other genes. Very limited population-based epidemiological data.

Chronic allergic conjunctivitis is a lifelong condition better characterized by prevalence. Estimated ~0.05% population prevalence (50 per 100k) based on ophthalmology literature and allergic disease epidemiology. Limited population-based prevalence data available; confidence capped at 0.55.
Rare endocrine disorder. Estimated ~1.5 per 100k children based on pediatric endocrinology case series; limited population-based epidemiological data available.

Tertiary hyperparathyroidism develops in chronic kidney disease/dialysis patients, typically after years of secondary hyperparathyroidism. Estimated incidence ~2 per 100k in dialysis population. Significant geographic variation based on dialysis prevalence and phosphate binder usage.
source_type: Nephrology registries and dialysis patient databases

is_subtype: Warm AIHA (IgG-mediated) represents 70-80% of autoimmune hemolytic anemias. Estimated incidence ~1-2 per 100k person-years. Limited epidemiological data; estimate based on hematology literature and disease frequency studies.
Congenital leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD) is extremely rare genetic immunodeficiency. Fewer than 300 cases documented worldwide; estimated <0.01 per 100k births.

Umbrella term too heterogeneous to meaningfully estimate: includes hereditary deficiencies (C1, C2, C3, C4, factors), acquired deficiencies, dysregulation disorders. No defined boundaries between inherited and acquired; prevalence ranges 0.01-1% depending on subtype.

Lyme carditis is a rare cardiac manifestation of Lyme disease, occurring in 0.3-5% of Lyme cases. Global Lyme incidence ~10-20 per 100k in endemic areas, so cardiac complications estimated ~0.5 per 100k globally. Moderate confidence due to geographic concentration and limited epidemiological data.
source_type: Steere AC et al. (2016). Lyme borreliosis. Nat Rev Dis Primers. 2:16090

is_subtype: Acute myocarditis from viral etiology, reported incidence approximately 1-2 per 100k person-years based on epidemiological studies and cardiac registries. Viral myocarditis represents subset of all myocarditis cases.
source_type: Cooper LT et al. (2007). The role of endomyocardial biopsy in the management of cardiovascular disease. Eur Heart J. 28(19):2319-2333

is_subtype: Candida albicans is the most common cause of candidiasis. Incidence varies widely by setting and population (immunocompromised vs. healthy). Estimated ~5 per 100k person-years globally, but highly dependent on HIV/AIDS prevalence and healthcare-associated infection rates.

Physical addiction is a symptom/component of substance use disorder rather than a distinct disease. Using prevalence estimate ~2.5% of global population with various addictions (alcohol, drugs). Low confidence due to heterogeneous category.

cui_name: Malignant neoplasm of stomach stage III
is_subtype: Stage III gastric cancer represents locally advanced disease. Global gastric cancer incidence ~10-15 per 100k. Stage III accounts for ~25-30% of cases. Estimated ~4 per 100k.

cui_name: Non-small cell lung cancer stage II
is_subtype: NSCLC stage II represents ~25% of NSCLC diagnoses. Global NSCLC incidence ~11 per 100k from GLOBOCAN 2005; stage II estimated at ~2.8 per 100k. Confidence limited by unavailability of stage-specific data in primary registries.
source_type: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC) - stage distribution estimates

cui_name: Stage I Ovarian Cancer AJCC v6 and v7
is_subtype: Stage I ovarian cancer under AJCC v6 and v7 classifications. Estimated ~1.6 per 100k based on proportional analysis of GLOBOCAN 2005 ovarian cancer incidence (~10 per 100k) with ~16% of cases presenting as Stage I.
source_type: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC), proportional stage estimates from cancer registries

is_subtype: Lung neuroendocrine carcinomas represent 20-25% of lung malignancies. SEER database studies show incidence increased from 0.3 per 100k (1973) to 1.35 per 100k (2004). Large cell neuroendocrine carcinoma specifically ~0.3 per 100k, carcinoid tumors ~0.7-1.0 per 100k. Using overall pulmonary NEN incidence of ~1.35 per 100k.
source_type: Incidence and Survival Outcomes in Patients with Lung Neuroendocrine Neoplasms in the United States - PMC8067543; SEER surveillance data 1973-2004

cui_name: Stage III Cutaneous Melanoma AJCC v6
is_subtype: Stage III melanoma represents regional lymph node involvement. Global melanoma incidence ~20 per 100k; Stage III comprises ~15-20% of melanoma cases, estimated ~3-4 per 100k. Data from GLOBOCAN and cancer registries with stage-specific breakdowns.
source_type: GLOBOCAN 2005 melanoma incidence data with AJCC staging distribution

is_subtype: Childhood-specific variant of pleomorphic RMS. Since RMS predominantly affects children, this is essentially equivalent to C0334480. Estimated ~0.4 per 100k in pediatric population. Limited specific epidemiological data on histological subtypes in childhood populations.

cui_name: Small cell carcinoma of the cervix
is_subtype: Small cell carcinoma of cervix is rare subtype (~1-2% of cervical cancers). Estimated ~1.5 per 100k based on cervical cancer incidence (12 per 100k globally) multiplied by small cell prevalence within cervical cancers.
source_type: Estimated from GLOBOCAN cervical cancer data

is_subtype: Mature cystic teratomas (dermoid cysts) are the most common ovarian tumor in reproductive-age women, occurring in ~1-2% of women, representing ~45% of ovarian tumors. Incidence ~40-60 per 100k, prevalence ~1000 per 100k.
source_type: Ulbright TM. (2005). Germ cell tumors of the gonads: a selective review emphasizing problems in differential diagnosis, newly recognized entities, and long-term follow-up. Mod Pathol. 18(2):S61-S79

is_subtype: Bladder cancer incidence globally ~9-10 per 100k. However, 'stage' descriptor suggests clinical staging context rather than a distinct epidemiological entity. Using general bladder cancer incidence with reduced confidence due to ambiguous CUI specification.
source_type: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC)

is_subtype: Basaloid carcinoma is a specific histological subtype of anal carcinoma. Anal cancer incidence ~1-2 per 100k globally; basaloid variant represents ~20-30% of anal cancers. Estimated 0.15-0.3 per 100k. Based on cancer registries with histological subtype data.
source_type: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC), including histological subtype analysis from WHO classification

is_subtype: Bile duct cancer incidence ~1.2 per 100k globally from GLOBOCAN 2005. Adult-onset subtype represents majority of cases.
source_type: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC)

is_subtype: Umbrella term describing reduced bone marrow function - symptom rather than specific disease. Encompasses aplastic anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and various other conditions with vastly different etiologies and incidence rates. Too heterogeneous for meaningful estimation.

Papillary meningiomas are rare aggressive subtypes, estimated at ~3-5% of all meningiomas. With overall meningioma incidence ~7-8 per 100k, papillary represents ~0.3 per 100k. Low confidence due to limited epidemiological data.
Rare X-linked dominant skeletal dysplasia. Estimated <0.05 per 100k births based on case report frequency. No systematic epidemiological studies; confidence limited by minimal available data.

Toxic thyroid adenoma (Plummer's disease) is a functioning thyroid adenoma causing thyrotoxicosis. Incidence ~2 per 100k person-years based on epidemiological studies; prevalence ~4-5 per 100k population. Accounts for 5-10% of hyperthyroidism cases. Specific disease entity with identifiable epidemiology.
source_type: Boelaert K et al. (2006). Guidelines for the management of thyroid cancer in adults. Clin Endocrinol (Oxf). 81 Suppl 1:1-122

is_subtype: Testicular dysgenesis incidence estimated at ~15 per 100k male births. Part of testicular dysgenesis syndrome (TDS) spectrum affecting ~1% of male population. Data limited; confidence reduced due to diagnostic variability and heterogeneity of definitions.

Ambiguous umbrella term referring to air-filled cavities or cysts (pneumatoceles, pneumatosis, subpleural blebs). Could result from trauma, infection, or other pathology. Too heterogeneous and vague to estimate aggregate incidence meaningfully without anatomical or etiological specification.

In situ lobular carcinoma (ILBC) represents 10-20% of breast cancers globally. Based on GLOBOCAN 2005 breast cancer incidence (~40-45 per 100k women) and estimated 15% ILBC proportion = ~6-7 per 100k women.
source_type: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC), with proportion estimates from international breast pathology literature

is_subtype: Pleomorphic RMS is a rare histological variant of rhabdomyosarcoma. Overall RMS incidence ~3-5 per 100k in children; pleomorphic represents <15% of cases. Estimated ~0.4 per 100k. Limited specific epidemiological data on histological subtypes.

Congenital optic nerve underdevelopment. Incidence estimated ~1-2 per 100,000 live births based on pediatric ophthalmology case series. Represents approximately 1 in 10,000 live births in developed countries.

Non-arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (NAION) is an acute ischemic event affecting the optic nerve. Incidence estimates range 2-10 per 100k person-years globally, using conservative mid-range estimate of 6.5. Confidence moderate due to variable reporting across regions.

Transient global amnesia (TGA) is a well-recognized acute neurological syndrome with defined diagnostic criteria. Incidence estimated at 3-5 per 100k person-years from neurological literature and prospective studies. Point estimate of 3.5 per 100k used.
Salzmann nodular dystrophy is an extremely rare corneal dystrophy with <50 cases reported in medical literature. Incidence <0.01 per 100k based on case report frequency.

cui_name: Corneal Dystrophy, Juvenile Epithelial of Meesmann
is_subtype: Meesmann corneal dystrophy is a rare autosomal dominant inherited disorder affecting the corneal epithelium. Very rare condition with estimated <0.01 per 100k based on ophthalmology literature and case reports. Specific genetic subtype with limited epidemiological data.

Rare inherited retinal dystrophy with characteristic bull's eye appearance on fundoscopy. Estimated prevalence <0.1 per 100k based on ophthalmologic registries. Subtype of macular dystrophies with genetically heterogeneous etiology.
Congenital chylothorax is an extremely rare condition with <100 cases annually reported in literature. Incidence estimated <0.05 per 100k births based on case reports.

Induced/provoked ventricular tachycardia refers to sustained VT that is deliberately triggered during electrophysiology testing or occurs as an iatrogenic complication of cardiac procedures. Not a primary disease entity but rather a clinical manifestation or procedural outcome with unmeasurable population-level incidence.

Pancreatic cystadenoma is a rare benign cystic neoplasm, estimated incidence ~0.5 per 100k based on pancreatic cancer registry extrapolations. Data limited to small case series and institutional reviews; confidence moderate due to limited population-based epidemiological data.

Bacterial peritonitis is typically a secondary infection rather than a primary disease entity. Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) occurs in 10-30% of cirrhotic patients with ascites, but population-based incidence is difficult to quantify. Not tractable as standalone population-level metric.
Rare autosomal recessive genetic syndrome characterized by skeletal dysplasia, developmental delay, and hypogonadism. Fewer than 20 cases reported in medical literature. Incidence <0.01 per 100k.

Autosomal dominant hypoparathyroidism (ADH) is a rare endocrine disorder characterized by hypoparathyroidism with developmental abnormalities (GATA3 mutations). Incidence estimated ~0.5 per 100k person-years; prevalence ~3 per 100k. Mixed inheritance pattern; autosomal dominant form is minority of cases. Limited epidemiological data; confidence based on small clinical cohorts.
source_type: Thakker RV. (2011). Hypoparathyroidism. N Engl J Med. 364(10):934-947

is_subtype: Specific endocrine disorder with estimated prevalence 40-45 per million (4-4.5 per 100k) based on clinical case series. Incidence ~1.5 per 100k estimated from limited cohort studies. Data quality limited; most studies are single-center or registry-based.

Hereditary cerebrovascular amyloidosis (including familial cerebral amyloid angiopathy) is extremely rare. Fewer than 1000 cases reported globally. Incidence likely <0.01 per 100k. Often identified through genetic testing and family screening rather than population-based studies.

cui_name: Autosomal recessive hypophosphatemic vitamin D refractory rickets
is_subtype: Extremely rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder causing vitamin D-refractory rickets. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births based on case reports. Only ~100-200 cases reported in medical literature globally. Low confidence due to limited epidemiological data and reliance on case reports.
Rare mitochondrial disorder affecting ATP synthesis. Estimated <0.1 per 100k births based on case reports and mitochondrial disease frequency literature.
Renal-specific carnitine transport defect is a rare genetic disorder with no systematic epidemiological data available. Estimated extremely rare (<0.01 per 100k) based on limited case reports.
CETP deficiency is an extremely rare genetic disorder with fewer than 100 cases worldwide. Estimated <0.01 per 100k person-years based on case reports. No systematic epidemiological data available.

Cutaneous mastocytosis (skin limited) represents the majority of mastocytosis cases. Prevalence estimated 1-11 per 100k with median around 7.5 per 100k population. Incidence estimated 2-3 per 100k per year based on diagnosis rates. Moderate geographic variation based on European and North American registry data.
source_type: Clinical registry data and case series from European hematology centers

is_subtype: Hepatosplenic schistosomiasis is chronic stage of schistosomiasis mansoni/japonicum with liver/spleen involvement. Incidence ~2.5 per 100k in endemic regions; prevalence ~15 per 100k due to chronic nature. Global estimate limited; primarily endemic in Sub-Saharan Africa and parts of Middle East/Asia.
source_type: WHO schistosomiasis control program estimates and endemic country surveys

is_subtype: Benign ovarian teratomas account for ~2-3 per 100k incidence among women. Common gynecological tumor with specific anatomical location reducing confidence due to limited epidemiological data.
source_type: Gynecological oncology literature estimates

is_subtype: Skin papillomas (benign skin growths/warts) are common in general population with prevalence ~5% (5000 per 100k). Incidence of new lesions approximately 150 per 100k per year. Limited epidemiological registry data; confidence capped at 0.58 due to variable definitions and reporting.

Akinetic epilepsy (loss of muscle tone) is synonymous with atonic epilepsy. Rare seizure type, estimated incidence <1 per 100k. Primarily documented in severe childhood epilepsies. Limited epidemiological data for this specific seizure type.
Erythropoietic protoporphyria (ferrochelatase deficiency) extremely rare, ~0.1 per 100k births estimated from case reports. Limited epidemiological surveillance data.

Most common parotid gland tumor, estimated incidence 1-1.5 per 100k annually. Incidence varies by geographic region and case ascertainment methods. Limited modern epidemiological studies; estimates largely from historical hospital-based registries.
source_type: Otolaryngology literature and hospital tumor registries (2000-2010)

is_subtype: Breast sarcomas (phyllodes tumors, angiosarcoma, etc.) are rare, representing <1% of breast cancers. Estimated incidence approximately 0.3 per 100k globally. Limited epidemiological data; confidence capped at 0.4 due to rarity and sparse published incidence data.
Brainstem encephalitis is a rare subset of viral encephalitis. Estimated ~0.5 per 100k annual incidence based on case reports and regional surveillance data.

Paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration (PCD) is a rare neurological complication of underlying malignancy. Estimated ~0.2 per 100k based on case frequency in cancer populations and literature suggesting 1-2% of cancer patients develop some paraneoplastic manifestation. Confidence limited by lack of population-based registry data and highly variable detection rates.

Acute-onset vascular dementia is a rare subtype. Estimated incidence ~0.3 per 100k person-years. Limited epidemiological data; most vascular dementia develops gradually. Confidence moderate due to rarity and diagnostic uncertainty.

Subcortical vascular dementia (SIVD) is more common than acute-onset variant. Estimated incidence ~1-2 per 100k person-years based on dementia epidemiology studies. Represents ~20-30% of vascular dementia cases.
source_type: Dementia epidemiology literature

is_subtype: Benign neonatal epilepsy occurs in approximately 1-4 per 1000 live births. The nonfamilial form represents a subset of benign neonatal epilepsy cases, estimated at ~25-50% of cases. Incidence approximately 1.5 per 100k person-years when annualized across general population. Confidence limited by heterogeneous definitions and incomplete epidemiological data in literature.
Quadriplegic CP represents ~10-15% of all CP cases. Incidence ~1.5 per 100k live births; prevalence ~2,500 per 100k among affected population due to lifelong condition.
source_type: Surveillance of Cerebral Palsy in Europe (SCPE) database

is_subtype: Extremely rare congenital condition; estimated <0.01 per 100k births based on case reports. Limited systematic epidemiological data available.
Extremely rare inherited platelet disorder; <100 cases reported worldwide. Incidence <0.01 per 100k based on case reports only.
Rare autosomal recessive immunodeficiency; estimated 1-2 per million births globally (<0.02 per 100k). Data from case reports and immunodeficiency registries.

Dental agenesis (tooth agenesis) is a common developmental condition. Prevalence estimates range 0.1-10% depending on definition (isolated vs syndromic); using ~4.5% (45 per 1000) globally from dental epidemiology studies.
source_type: Dental epidemiology literature (prevalence studies)

is_subtype: Umbrella term without anatomic or etiologic specificity. 'Proliferative nephritis unspecified' is too vague to estimate meaningfully - would require specification of IgA nephropathy, lupus nephritis, MPGN, etc.

cui_name: Renal Tubular Acidosis, Distal, with Progressive Nerve Deafness
is_subtype: Rare genetic syndrome combining distal RTA with sensorineural hearing loss. Extremely rare, <0.01 per 100k births. Limited epidemiological data available; confidence based on case report frequency.

Transplant glomerulopathy is a chronic rejection pattern affecting kidney transplants. Estimated incidence based on graft pathology studies; occurs in 5-10% of long-term kidney transplant recipients. Limited to population receiving transplants.
Primary VUR (congenital) diagnosed in ~0.3-0.5% of live births in screening studies (~30-50 per 100k births). Incidence varies by screening protocols and genetic factors.

Rare genetic condition, estimated ~0.4 per 100k male births. Often associated with CFTR mutations in cystic fibrosis spectrum. Limited epidemiological data, estimates based on case report frequency and genetic association studies.

Broad umbrella term encompassing hypogonadism, erectile dysfunction, and infertility with highly variable etiologies and incidence rates. Estimated aggregate from primary hypogonadism (~2-3 per 100k) and secondary causes (~2-3 per 100k).

Extremely rare genetic syndrome with multiple hamartomas (lipomas) in brain, skull, and skin. Fewer than 100 cases reported worldwide. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births. Confidence limited by minimal epidemiological data and case report-based understanding.

Profound intellectual disability is a specific subtype characterized by IQ <20. Overall intellectual disability prevalence ~1-3% globally (10,000-30,000 per 100k), with severe and profound combined representing ~0.1% of population (1,000 per 100k). Profound specifically accounts for ~2% of ID cases, estimated at ~20 per 100k. Reported as prevalence (chronic lifelong condition) rather than incidence.
source_type: CDC NCHS Data Brief No. 473 (July 2023); Prevalence of Intellectual Disabilities - NCBI Bookshelf

is_subtype: Unilateral (one-sided) cryptorchidism represents majority of cryptorchidism cases. Global birth incidence estimated ~2-3 per 100k births. Limited epidemiological literature.
Thumb hypoplasia is a rare congenital anomaly with estimated incidence ~0.5 per 100k births based on birth defect registries. Reported as part of isolated thumb anomalies and syndromic conditions.
Refractory anemia (RA) is the most common subtype of MDS with incidence ~2-3 per 100k, primarily in elderly populations. Uses incidence metric as these are incident diagnoses.

Rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder affecting cranial and ectodermal structures. Type 1 is the most common form of cranioectodermal dysplasia but remains extremely rare with fewer than 50 families documented. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births.
Extremely rare autosomal recessive disorder combining progeria-like features with skeletal dysplasia. Fewer than 20 cases reported worldwide. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births.

Osteopathia striata is an extremely rare genetic skeletal dysplasia with autosomal dominant inheritance. Fewer than 100 cases reported worldwide, estimated <0.01 per 100k births. Benign course often detected incidentally on imaging.

cui_name: Severe combined immunodeficiency with low or normal B-cell numbers
is_subtype: Specific SCID subtype with B-cell presence but T-cell deficiency. Global SCID incidence ~1 per 100,000 live births; this phenotype represents approximately 20-30% of SCID cases, estimated at ~0.2 per 100k births.
source_type: Immunodeficiency registries and newborn screening data

is_subtype: Penoscrotal hypospadias represents a more severe anatomical variant of hypospadias. Overall hypospadias incidence is 0.5-8 per 1000 male births (average ~3.5 per 1000 births globally). Penoscrotal location comprises approximately 5-10% of hypospadias cases, estimated at ~1.2 per 100k births.
source_type: Epidemiology of hypospadias from urological surveys and birth defect registries

is_subtype: Receptive aphasia is a symptom/language disorder rather than a primary disease entity. Incidence depends on underlying etiology (stroke, dementia, brain injury, etc.). Cannot estimate meaningfully as a standalone condition without specifying primary disease.
High-grade B-cell lymphoma incidence approximately 3.2 per 100k globally from cancer registries. WHO/GLOBOCAN data shows consistent rates across regions.
source_type: Parkin DM et al. (2005). Global cancer statistics, 2002. CA Cancer J Clin. 55(2):74-108

is_subtype: Descriptive term for clinical finding rather than a specific disease entity. Encompasses benign cysts, lipomas, sarcomas, and numerous other conditions with vastly different epidemiologies.

Hereditary renal hypouricemia caused by urate transporter defects (URAT1, GLUT9 mutations). Estimated incidence 0.5-1.0 per 100k based on genetic disorder frequency. Type 1 more common in Asian populations. Low confidence due to limited global epidemiological data; most information from genetic studies and case series.
source_type: Enomoto A et al. (2002). Molecular identification of a renal urate anion exchanger that regulates blood urate levels. Nature. 417(6888):447-452

is_subtype: Chondrocalcinosis subtype with limited epidemiological data. Estimated ~1.5 per 100k based on arthritis registries, but specific 'other' category poorly defined.
Lung cancer adenocarcinoma is the most common histologic type (~40% of lung cancers). Global lung cancer incidence ~24 per 100k (GLOBOCAN 2005); adenocarcinoma represents ~9.5 per 100k.
source_type: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC)

is_subtype: Gallstone pancreatitis is the leading cause of acute pancreatitis in developed countries, accounting for ~40-50% of cases. Global acute pancreatitis incidence ~17-20 per 100k; gallstone-related represents approximately 40-50% of cases (~8.5 per 100k).

Rare autosomal recessive disorder of glycine cleavage system. Estimated <0.05 per 100k births based on case reports and biochemical screening studies. Very limited epidemiological data; estimates based on clinical case frequency.
Vague, non-specific umbrella term. 'Hypersensitive syndrome' lacks clinical coherence and cannot be mapped to a well-defined disease entity. Too broad for meaningful epidemiological estimation.
Primary glaucoma has high prevalence in older populations (~2.1% globally). Incidence of new cases estimated at 8.5 per 100k person-years. Data from WHO and population-based epidemiological studies.
source_type: Quigley HA, Broman AT. (2006). The number of people with glaucoma worldwide. Br J Ophthalmol. 90(3):262-267

is_subtype: Proliferative myositis is a rare inflammatory muscle condition with limited epidemiological documentation. Estimated incidence ~0.5 per 100k based on case reports and small cohort studies.

Lung cysts are typically benign incidental findings on imaging rather than clinical diagnoses. Not systematically tracked in disease registries. Incidence data not available; concept is poorly defined (includes simple cysts, blebs, cavitary lesions).
Rare skeletal dysplasia characterized by shortening of middle long bones; umbrella term for several distinct genetic conditions. Estimated <0.1 per 100k births based on case reports.
Rare juvenile soft tissue neoplasm, most common in hands and feet. Estimated <0.1 per 100k based on case reports and orthopedic registries. Fewer than 1000 documented cases worldwide.
source_type: Kransdorf MJ et al. (1991). Calcifying aponeurotic fibroma: radiologic appearance with pathologic correlation. Radiographics. 11(3):365-376

is_subtype: Rare autosomal recessive metabolic disorder affecting leucine metabolism. Type 3 is a specific subtype. Estimated incidence <0.1 per 100k births. Population-based epidemiological data not available; limited to case reports and registry data.

Umbrella term too vague and broad to estimate meaningfully. 'Cortex bone disorders' lacks clear definition: could refer to osteoporosis, cortical bone lesions, osteonecrosis, or other bone cortex pathology. Term requires clinical specification (osteoporosis, cortical thickening disorder, etc.) to provide meaningful epidemiological estimate.

Umbrella term encompassing depression, anxiety, and emotional disturbance. Aggregate estimate of major mental health conditions: depression (~10,000), anxiety disorders (~20,000), adjustment disorders (~15,000) prevalence per 100k. Highly heterogeneous category with significant overlap.
Not a disease entity. 'Relief drinking' is a behavioral descriptor/risk factor for alcohol use disorder, not a mappable disease condition for incidence estimation.

Familial alcoholism measured as prevalence (~0.5% of population with family history predisposition). Limited epidemiological data specific to familial cases; using proxy estimate from alcohol use disorder prevalence literature.

Vascular rupture is a pathological process/acute event rather than a specific disease entity. Incidence depends on underlying condition (AAA, cerebral aneurysm, aortic dissection, etc.). Cannot estimate meaningfully without specifying primary vascular disease.

Pathological finding/descriptor rather than a specific disease entity. 'Lesion' is too generic and covers benign and malignant conditions with vastly different epidemiologies (ulcers, gastritis, gastric cancer, polyps).
Infantile neuroaxonal dystrophy (INAD) is a rare lysosomal storage disorder with autosomal recessive inheritance. Estimated <0.5 per 100k births based on rare genetic disease registries.

cui_name: Secondary malignant neoplasm of lymph nodes of neck
is_subtype: Unmappable secondary diagnosis representing metastatic spread to cervical lymph nodes from unspecified primary cancers. Incidence depends entirely on primary cancer type and cannot be estimated independently. Requires specification of primary malignancy.
CUI C0694571 not found in epidemiological database

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), primarily 21-hydroxylase deficiency. Global incidence ~1/10,000 to 1/15,000 live births (~7-10 per 100k). Relatively well-documented through newborn screening programs and clinical registries.
source_type: WHO Endocrine Disorders database and newborn screening registries

is_subtype: Granular cell tumors are rare benign soft tissue neoplasms with estimated incidence 0.1-0.3 per 100k. Limited epidemiological data; mostly documented in case series and tumor registries.

Not a disease entity but a medical procedure/device. AV grafts are surgically created vascular access conduits used in dialysis treatment for end-stage renal disease. Incidence would reflect dialysis procedures, not disease epidemiology.

PTSD prevalence estimated at 3.5% of global population (3,500 per 100k). Chronic PTSD is a subtype/progression of acute PTSD. Used prevalence metric as incidence is poorly defined for psychiatric conditions. Data from meta-analyses and WHO estimates.
source_type: Kessler RC et al. (2005). Lifetime and 12-month prevalence of DSM-IV disorders in the United States. J Clin Psychiatry. 66(5):617-627

is_subtype: Hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis is a secondary electrolyte disorder rather than a primary disease entity. Incidence difficult to determine as it complicates multiple primary conditions (hyperemesis, diuretic use, vomiting). Estimated ~75 per 100k person-years based on hospital discharge diagnosis data. Low confidence due to inability to separate primary vs. secondary occurrence.

Atypical/variant angina presentations represent significant portion of angina diagnoses (~30-40% of chest pain presentations). Global angina incidence estimated 30-40 per 100k, so atypical variant ~10-15 per 100k. Used incidence metric appropriate for incident cardiac diagnoses. Confidence moderate due to diagnostic variability in defining 'atypical.'

Umbrella term too broad and generic. Encompasses hypertension, atherosclerosis, arrhythmias, valvular disease, heart failure, and other pathological conditions affecting the cardiovascular system. Cannot be meaningfully aggregated without disease-specific data.

Aggregate BOTEC estimate summing major carotid disease categories: carotid atherosclerosis (~350 per 100k), carotid dissection (~1-3 per 100k), carotid stenosis (subset of atherosclerosis), fibromuscular dysplasia (~2 per 100k), other carotid pathology. Total aggregate ~450 per 100k. Heterogeneous umbrella term with significant overlap between categories and varying clinical significance.

Metastatic/advanced cervical cancer represents ~20-25% of newly diagnosed cervical cancer cases (global cervical cancer incidence ~10 per 100k in women, so metastatic incidence ~2-2.5 per 100k).
