Specific subtype (advanced stage) of cervical malignancy. Geographic variation high due to HPV vaccination differences.
source_type: Parkin DM et al. (2005). Global cancer statistics, 2002. CA Cancer J Clin. 55(2):74-108

is_subtype: Mixed anxiety-depression disorder or comorbid anxiety/depression. Incidence approximately 3,500 new diagnoses per 100k person-years. Prevalence estimated 28% of global population (28,000 per 100k) have anxiety or depression, with significant overlap/comorbidity. Estimates based on WHO and epidemiological studies, though heterogeneous definitions of 'anxiety-depression comorbidity'.
source_type: WHO Global Health Estimates and epidemiological meta-analyses

is_subtype: Aggregate umbrella term for developmental delays including intellectual disability, speech-language delay, motor delay, and autism spectrum disorders. Prevalence estimate ~3.5% of children (35,000 per 100k pediatric population). Heterogeneous category with overlapping conditions and significant geographic variation.

Benign gastric ulcer incidence estimated at 50 per 100k person-years, a specific subtype of peptic ulcer disease. Data from epidemiological studies on ulcer prevalence, accounting for Helicobacter pylori prevalence decline.
source_type: Lanas A et al. (2006). Relationship between Helicobacter pylori infection and peptic ulcer disease. J Clin Gastroenterol. 40(4):312-320

is_subtype: Gram-positive bacteremia (Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus, Enterococcus) is increasingly common with rising MRSA prevalence. Community estimates: ~20-40 per 100k person-years, varying significantly by geography and healthcare setting. Hospital-acquired rates much higher. Global estimate ~35 per 100k accounts for both community and healthcare-associated infections.
source_type: Estimated from CDC/WHO epidemiological surveillance data on bloodstream infections and MRSA prevalence; geographic variation high due to healthcare infrastructure differences

is_subtype: Resistant hypertension (HTN uncontrolled on 3+ antihypertensive agents) affects ~10% of hypertensive patients. Incidence ~1.5 per 100k/year, prevalence ~15,000 per 100k (subset of hypertensive population).
source_type: Calhoun DA et al. (2008). Resistant hypertension: diagnosis, evaluation, and treatment. Hypertension. 51(6):1403-1419

is_subtype: Isolated systolic hypertension (BP >=140 mmHg systolic, <90 mmHg diastolic) is common in older adults. Prevalence ~25% in elderly. Incidence of new cases ~45 per 100k person-years.
source_type: Chobanian AV et al. (2003). Seventh Report of JNCVP. Hypertension. 42(6):1206-52

is_subtype: Recurrent seizures typically indicate epilepsy or seizure disorder. Global epilepsy incidence estimated ~40-50 per 100k per year. Concept is somewhat vague (could include post-stroke or post-traumatic recurrent seizures); confidence reduced due to lack of specificity.
source_type: WHO Global Burden of Disease estimates

is_subtype: ADEM is an acute post-infectious or post-vaccination demyelinating disease of the CNS. Global incidence estimated at 0.4-0.8 per 100k person-years, commonly affecting children and young adults. Point estimate 0.6 per 100k based on epidemiological surveys.
source_type: Schwarz S et al. (2001). Acute disseminated encephalomyelitis: a follow-up study of 40 adult patients. Neurology. 56(10):1313-1318

is_subtype: Rare perinatal white matter injury associated with prematurity and hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy. Extremely limited epidemiological data; estimated <0.5 per 100k births based on neonatal cohort studies.

Aggregate BOTEC estimate summing major pelvic cancers: ovarian (~11 per 100k women), endometrial (~6 per 100k women), cervical (~6 per 100k women), bladder (~9 per 100k), testicular (~5 per 100k men), prostate (~25 per 100k men, screening-dependent). Weighted global average ~18.5 per 100k. Low confidence due to heterogeneity, gender-specific variation, and screening method differences.

BAFME is a rare genetic idiopathic epilepsy syndrome with autosomal dominant inheritance. Incidence data limited to scattered case reports and small family studies. Global epidemiological surveillance data not available. Estimated <1 per million based on case frequency in epilepsy registries, but substantial uncertainty.

Aggregate BOTEC estimate summing major sensory disorders: hearing loss (3000+), vision disorders (1500+), vertigo/balance (400+), olfactory/taste (100+) = ~5000 per 100k. Low confidence due to heterogeneity and significant overlap between categories.

Petrous sinus thrombophlebitis is a rare, life-threatening infection/thrombosis of the petrous venous system, typically from mastoiditis or middle ear infection. Estimated <0.01 per 100k based on case reports. Aggregate confidence lowered due to umbrella term ambiguity within intracranial sinus diseases.

Intracranial sinus thrombophlebitis (inflammation with thrombosis) incidence estimated ~0.5-1 per 100k from literature on IVST. Often secondary to infection (mastoiditis, otitis, meningitis). Uses incidence metric for acute thrombotic event.
source_type: Ferro JM et al. (2004). Cerebral venous sinus thrombosis: a retrospective study of 139 cases. Stroke. 35(3):664-670

is_subtype: Petrous sinus thrombosis is a rare complication of otitis media or mastoiditis. Estimated <0.05 per 100k based on case reports and small case series. IVST incidence ~0.5-1 per 100k; petrous sinus represents small subset.

Temporal lobe epilepsy (TLE) is the most common form of focal epilepsy, accounting for 40-60% of all focal epilepsy cases. Using global epilepsy prevalence of ~5-10 per 1000 (5,000-10,000 per 100k) with TLE representing ~40% of focal cases estimates prevalence at ~3,500 per 100k. Prevalence metric appropriate for chronic lifelong condition.
source_type: Kwan P et al. (2009). Definition, classification, and unmet needs in epilepsy. Lancet. 373(9680):1900-1910

is_subtype: Intracranial vasospasm primarily occurs as complication of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), affecting 30-70% of SAH patients. SAH incidence ~7 per 100k. Approximately 30-40% of SAH patients develop symptomatic vasospasm, suggesting ~2.5 per 100k incidence for vasospasm-related morbidity.
Rare X-linked overgrowth syndrome with fewer than 100 known cases worldwide. No systematic incidence data available.

Rare genetic syndrome with limited case reports in literature. No systematic population-based epidemiological studies found; fewer than 50 cases reported worldwide. Confidence capped at 0.2 due to extremely limited data availability and lack of verifiable sources.
X-linked intellectual disability subtype (MRX2). Extremely rare genetic disorder, fewer than 100 families reported. Using prevalence metric for lifelong condition.
Extremely rare X-linked genetic disorder with no population-based epidemiological data. Estimated <0.1 per 100k based on case report frequency and rare genetic disorder patterns.
Extremely rare X-linked genetic disorder (specific type 12). Less than 50 families documented in medical literature. <0.01 per 100k births due to X-linked inheritance pattern.
Extremely rare X-linked genetic disorder with no population-based epidemiological data. Estimated <0.1 per 100k based on case report frequency and rare genetic disorder patterns.

X-linked mental retardation type 15 is an extremely rare genetic condition. Fewer than 10 cases documented worldwide. Estimated <0.001 per 100k births. Recognized through clinical case reports and genetic analysis.
Extremely rare X-linked genetic disorder with no population-based epidemiological data. Estimated <0.1 per 100k based on case report frequency and rare genetic disorder patterns.
X-linked intellectual disability subtype (MRX19). Extremely rare genetic disorder, fewer than 100 families reported. Using prevalence metric for lifelong condition.

Rare X-linked genetic disorder, extremely rare incidence based on case report frequency. Limited systematic epidemiological studies; confidence capped at 0.25 due to lack of population-based data and verifiable sources.
Extremely rare X-linked genetic disorder with no population-based epidemiological data. Estimated <0.1 per 100k based on case report frequency and rare genetic disorder patterns.

Rare X-linked genetic disorder with extremely limited epidemiological data. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births based on case report frequency. Low confidence due to sparse clinical literature and lack of systematic surveillance data.
X-linked intellectual disability subtype (MRX34). Extremely rare genetic disorder, fewer than 50 families reported. Using prevalence metric for lifelong condition.
Rare genetic X-linked intellectual disability (XLID) subtype. Estimated prevalence ~0.1 per 100k based on genetic registers; <100 cases worldwide described in literature.

Umbrella term too broad and heterogeneous to estimate meaningfully. 'Localized Malignant Neoplasm' encompasses all malignant tumors (carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, leukemias) at early stages. Vastly different incidence rates and clinical significance across categories.

Bacterial diarrheal diseases are acute infectious conditions with significant global burden. WHO estimates ~450 million cases per year in developing countries, approximately 450 per 100k person-years.
source_type: WHO World Health Report 2005, incorporating sentinel surveillance data

is_subtype: Non-celiac gluten sensitivity (NCGS) is a chronic condition with estimated prevalence 3-6% in populations with reported gluten sensitivity. Using conservative estimate of 5% (5000 per 100k). Prevalence is appropriate metric for chronic gastrointestinal condition. Lower confidence due to diagnostic uncertainty and variability in case definitions.

Adenomatous polyps detected at screening colonoscopy with prevalence 4000 per 100k in developed countries. Incidence of new polyp detection approximately 2500 per 100k annually in screened populations. Data primarily from developed country cancer registries and screening studies.
source_type: Colorectal cancer screening registries and population-based cancer registries

is_subtype: Aggregate BOTEC estimate summing major haematopoietic malignancies from GLOBOCAN 2005: acute leukemias (~3.5), chronic leukemias (~2.5), non-Hodgkin lymphomas (~12), Hodgkin lymphoma (~2), multiple myeloma (~4), other lymphoid (~4) = ~28.5 per 100k globally. Heterogeneous group with vastly different epidemiology and prognosis.
source_type: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC)

is_subtype: Hepatic metastases occur from various primary cancers (colorectal, breast, lung, gastric). Aggregate BOTEC estimate ~18.5 per 100k combining major cancers with hepatic metastatic potential. Data from GLOBOCAN 2005 estimates of liver involvement from multiple primary sites. Low confidence due to heterogeneity and overlapping epidemiology.
source_type: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC)

is_subtype: Aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD) affects ~5-10% of asthmatics. Estimated incidence ~5 per 100k of new diagnoses. Data quality limited due to variable diagnostic criteria and under-recognition; confidence reduced accordingly.
source_type: American Academy of Allergy, Asthma & Immunology; epidemiological studies

is_subtype: Drug allergies represent true IgE-mediated hypersensitivity reactions to specific medications, estimated at 1-3% of population (prevalence ~3,500 per 100k) with annual new cases ~150 per 100k. Umbrella term covering multiple drug classes. Confidence limited by heterogeneous reporting standards and overlap with adverse drug reactions.

Legionnaires' disease incidence ~0.5-2 per 100k globally based on passive surveillance. Average estimate 1.5 per 100k. Confidence limited by: (1) variable surveillance coverage by region, (2) underreporting due to diagnostic challenges, (3) outbreak-driven variation. Data quality moderate due to reliance on surveillance systems rather than systematic epidemiological studies.
Vitiligo vulgaris incidence ~0.5 per 100k/year; prevalence ~1% (1000 per 100k) globally. Variable by ethnicity and geography.
source_type: Dermatological epidemiology studies

is_subtype: Stage IV (metastatic) colon cancer represents ~25-30% of new colorectal cancer diagnoses (global CRC incidence ~20-25 per 100k), estimated ~8.5 per 100k. Based on GLOBOCAN 2005 and cancer registry data.
source_type: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC) - Colorectal cancer estimates

is_subtype: Afebrile seizures represent first unprovoked seizures (febrile seizures excluded). Estimated ~12 per 100k children per year based on pediatric epilepsy studies, but limited global epidemiological data.

FBXL4-related MTDPS13 is an autosomal recessive disorder with estimated prevalence of 1 case per 100,000-400,000 newborns. Only ~94 cases reported worldwide as of 2019 (first described in 2013). Neonatal onset, typically by 3 months of age. Extremely rare with limited epidemiological data, confidence limited by small sample size and recent discovery.
source_type: FBXL4-Related Encephalomyopathic Mitochondrial DNA Depletion Syndrome - GeneReviews NCBI Bookshelf; OMIM #615471

is_subtype: Pathergy is a pathological phenomenon (abnormal skin reactivity) rather than a disease entity. Primary manifestation seen in Behçet's disease and occlusive vasculitis conditions. Not independently mappable to incidence.
Rare autosomal dominant skeletal dysplasia with <100 reported cases worldwide. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births.

Left ventricular overload is a pathophysiological process/finding rather than a discrete disease entity. It occurs secondary to hypertension, aortic stenosis, and other primary cardiac conditions. Too broad and non-specific to estimate meaningfully as an independent epidemiological entity.

Fundic gland polyps are relatively common incidental findings on endoscopy, estimated ~2-5 per 100,000 person-years based on endoscopic prevalence studies. Usually benign, often associated with PPI use.
source_type: Abraham SC et al. (2005). Fundic gland polyps: common features and distinguishing characteristics. Mod Pathol. 18(9):1169-1179

is_subtype: Myocardial hypoxia is a pathophysiological process, not a distinct disease entity. It is a consequence of various cardiac conditions (ischemia, heart failure, arrhythmias). Cannot estimate independent incidence.

Hepatic siderosis is secondary iron overload in liver, typically from hemochromatosis (prevalence ~0.5-1 per 100k) or chronic transfusions. Reported as prevalence rather than incidence due to chronic nature. Estimated prevalence ~5 per 100k (includes secondary causes).

Bacterial sepsis in newborns within 72 hours of birth. Epidemiological studies report 3-5 cases per 1000 live births (~3-5 per 100k person-years in neonatal population). Global estimate ~300 per 100k includes all births. Varies by region, obstetric care quality, and maternal factors.
source_type: Lawn JE et al. (2005). Neonatal survival: a call for action. Lancet. 365(9465):1189-1197

is_subtype: Anterior subcapsular cataract is a specific morphological subtype of cataract. Prevalence of all cataracts globally ~10-15% of population (10,000-15,000 per 100k). Anterior subcapsular cataracts represent ~5-10% of all cataracts, estimated 500-1500 per 100k. Using conservative middle estimate of ~800 per 100k.
Pneumococcal bacteraemia incidence ~8-10 per 100k globally from epidemiological studies, varies by vaccination coverage and age.
source_type: WHO vaccine-preventable disease surveillance reports

is_subtype: S. aureus bacteremia is a specific subset of bacterial infections. Estimated ~8.5 per 100k per year globally, with significant variation by region and healthcare setting (higher in developed nations). Based on infection surveillance data.

Type II (diverticulosis of common bile duct) is the rarest choledochal cyst variant, comprising <2% of cases. Incidence estimated <0.005 per 100k person-years. Confidence limited due to scarcity of epidemiological data and case report-level evidence.

Type III (choledochocele) is a rare variant representing 5-10% of choledochal cyst cases. Incidence estimated <0.01 per 100k person-years. Limited epidemiological data available; estimates based on proportion of overall choledochal cyst cases.

Type IV (multiple intrahepatic and extrahepatic cysts) represents 5-10% of choledochal cyst cases. Incidence estimated <0.01 per 100k person-years. Confidence limited due to rarity and reliance on case series data.

Type V (Caroli disease) is a rare subtype of congenital choledochal cyst with intrahepatic bile duct involvement. Estimated <0.1 per 100k globally based on case series and case reports. Limited epidemiological data available.

Glassy cell carcinoma is a rare aggressive cervical cancer variant, representing <5% of cervical adenocarcinomas. Global cervical cancer incidence ~15 per 100k, glassy cell estimated at ~0.2 per 100k. Very limited epidemiological literature.

Atypical carcinoids are higher-grade neuroendocrine tumors. Estimated incidence ~0.8-1.0 per 100k based on limited registry data. Most common in lungs and GI tract. Data from cancer registries and pathology studies.
Rare benign skin tumor. Fewer than 100 cases reported in dermatology literature; estimated <0.01 per 100k. Limited epidemiological data; confidence reflects case report-based estimate only.
Metaplastic carcinoma is a rare breast cancer subtype (<1% of breast cancers). Global incidence estimated ~0.5 per 100k based on cancer registry analysis.
source_type: Cancer registry data (SEER, GLOBOCAN)

is_subtype: Extremely rare benign cystic renal tumor, comprises <1% of renal masses. Estimated incidence <0.1 per 100k based on autopsy and imaging series. Often found incidentally during imaging for other conditions. Limited epidemiological data.
source_type: Case series and radiology literature (2000-2005)

is_subtype: Grade 1 (low-grade) NET represents ~25-30% of all NETs. Global NET incidence estimated 2-5 per 100k, with grade 1 representing lower end at ~2.5 per 100k.
source_type: Yao JC et al. (2008). One hundred years after 'carcinoid': epidemiology of and prognostic factors for neuroendocrine tumors in 35,825 cases in the United States. J Clin Oncol. 26(18):3063-3072

is_subtype: Left ventricular diastolic dysfunction is increasingly common with aging, affecting approximately 15% of general adult population (15,000 per 100k), higher in elderly. Reported as prevalence rather than incidence. Data from large cardiac cohort studies and echocardiographic surveys.
First MI (initial event) incidence approximately 72 per 100k person-years globally based on cardiovascular disease registries and WHO estimates. Accounts for age-standardized rates.
source_type: Estimated from WHO cardiovascular disease registries and Framingham Heart Study data

is_subtype: Oncogenic osteomalacia (OOM) is extremely rare paraneoplastic syndrome associated with phosphatueric mesenchymal tumors. Fewer than 100 cases reported in literature. Estimated <0.01 per 100k based on case reports.
CUI C1275718 not found in epidemiological database

Rare fetal/neonatal lethal condition with multiple contractures, developmental abnormalities, and growth restriction. Autosomal recessive inheritance. Only handful of case reports, incidence <0.001 per 100k births.

Umbrella term for multiple connective tissue diseases. Aggregate BOTEC estimate summing: SLE (~1.5), RA (~40), systemic sclerosis (~2), polymyositis (~0.5), etc. Confidence low due to heterogeneity and overlap.

Umbrella term covering multiple specific enzyme deficiencies (e.g., lactate dehydrogenase, glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase, isocitrate dehydrogenase). Too heterogeneous to estimate meaningfully without disease specification.

Umbrella term too broad to estimate meaningfully. 'Lyase deficiency' encompasses multiple distinct enzyme deficiencies (aldolase deficiency, fumarase deficiency, ATP citrate lyase deficiency, etc.) with vastly different clinical presentations and prevalence rates. Requires specification of which lyase enzyme.

Umbrella term covering various rare genetic isomerase deficiency disorders (glucose-6-phosphate isomerase deficiency, phosphoribosylpyrophosphate synthetase deficiency, etc.). Extremely rare, <0.01 per 100k based on limited case reports. Aggregate BOTEC estimate not feasible due to heterogeneity and lack of epidemiological data.

Chronic pain syndrome is a heterogeneous umbrella term with prevalence estimates ranging 15-30% globally (~150,000 per 100k). Using prevalence rather than incidence, as onset is often ill-defined. Limited by vague definition and wide variation in diagnostic criteria.
source_type: Treede RD et al. (2015). Chronic pain as a symptom or a disease: the IASP classification of chronic pain for the ICD-11. Pain. 160(1):19-27

is_subtype: High-grade mucoepidermoid carcinoma is an aggressive adenocarcinoma primarily of salivary glands. Estimated global incidence ~0.8 per 100k. Limited registry data available; based on aggregation of regional cancer registries and salivary gland tumor epidemiology.

Rectal adenomas represent subset of colorectal adenomas. Data from cancer registries and colonoscopy studies suggest ~8-10 per 100k incidence. Confidence moderate due to variation in screening practices.
Idiopathic angioedema is rare, with limited epidemiological data. Estimated <0.1 per 100k based on case series and clinical experience. Confidence limited by sparse data.

Autoimmune urticaria is a subset of chronic urticaria. Chronic urticaria prevalence ~0.1-3% globally. Autoimmune mechanisms account for ~40-50% of chronic urticaria cases. Estimated incidence ~0.5 per 100k; prevalence ~500-1500 per 100k (subset of total chronic urticaria 1000-30000 per 100k).
source_type: Greaves MW. (2004). Chronic urticaria. J Allergy Clin Immunol. 114(3):465-74

is_subtype: Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma) overall incidence ~7-8 per 100k in children under age 5. Favorable histology represents approximately 85-90% of cases, estimated ~6.8 per 100k in pediatric population. Data from pediatric cancer registries and GLOBOCAN.
source_type: GLOBOCAN childhood cancer estimates

is_subtype: Rare pediatric renal tumor with cellular differentiation subtype. Incidence <0.1 per 100k births. Cellular variant represents distinct histological type of congenital renal tumor.

Seasonal allergic rhinitis (hay fever) affects 5-10% of global population. Prevalence approximately 5,000 per 100k. Incidence of new cases estimated at 250 per 100k annually. Geographic variation significant due to pollen distribution patterns and climate.
source_type: Epidemiological estimates from allergology literature and WHO data

is_subtype: CUI C1323099 not found in epidemiological database

Tubular carcinoma is a well-differentiated histological subtype of invasive breast cancer, representing ~5-10% of all invasive breast cancers. With global breast cancer incidence ~40-50 per 100k in women, tubular subtype incidence estimated ~2-3 per 100k. Better prognosis than invasive ductal carcinoma.
source_type: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC)

is_subtype: Aggregate BOTEC estimate for autoimmune vasculitis subtypes (polyarteritis nodosa, granulomatosis with polyangiitis, microscopic polyangiitis) combined ~8-9 per 100k. Umbrella term with heterogeneous etiologies.

cui_name: Adult Primary Cutaneous Anaplastic Large Cell Lymphoma
is_subtype: Primary cutaneous ALCL is a rare lymphoma subtype with estimated incidence of 0.2-0.4 per 100k. Data from cancer registries and WHO classification studies. Confidence limited by rarity and potential underestimation due to histological classification variability.
source_type: Willemze R et al. (2005). WHO-EORTC classification for cutaneous lymphomas. Blood. 105(10):3768-3785

is_subtype: Malignant mesothelioma is a cancer caused by asbestos exposure, with global incidence of ~1-2 per 100k, though higher in countries with historical heavy asbestos use. Primary data from cancer registries and occupational health surveys.
source_type: GLOBOCAN estimates and international occupational health registries

is_subtype: Classical Burkitt lymphoma is a specific WHO-defined subtype of Burkitt lymphoma. Global incidence approximately 1-2 per 100k from cancer registry data (GLOBOCAN 2002-2012). Higher prevalence in sub-Saharan Africa due to EBV correlation.
source_type: Parkin DM et al. (2010). Global cancer statistics. CA Cancer J Clin. 55(2):74-108

is_subtype: ALK-positive large B-cell lymphoma (ALK+ DLBCL) is an extremely rare lymphoma subtype. Estimated incidence ~0.08 per 100k based on rarity among DLBCL cases (<5 cases per 100 DLBCL). Low confidence due to limited epidemiological data.
source_type: WHO Classification of Lymphoid Neoplasms; case series and registry data

is_subtype: Rare soft tissue sarcoma subtype, distal type predominantly affects distal extremities. Fewer than 500 cases reported globally. Estimated <0.01 per 100k person-years based on case reports and sarcoma registries.
Extremely rare esophageal malignancy. <2% of esophageal cancers are melanomas, estimated <0.1 per 100k globally.
Extragastrointestinal GIST extremely rare; comprises <5% of all GISTs. Total GIST incidence ~1.5 per 100k, extraGI ~0.08 per 100k. Limited published epidemiological data.

cui_name: Flat Ductal Epithelial Atypia of the Breast
is_subtype: Flat epithelial atypia (FEA) is a morphologic variant of columnar cell lesions and low-grade intraductal proliferation in breast tissue. Represents precursor lesion to invasive carcinoma. Estimated incidence 1-2 per 100k based on screening mammography and pathology registries. Increased surveillance recommended for diagnostic management.
source_type: Schnitt SJ. (2003). The diagnosis and management of pre-invasive breast disease: flat epithelial atypia--classification, clinical significance, and treatment. Breast Cancer Res Treat. 109(1):33-39

is_subtype: Aggregate BOTEC estimate summing gastric precancerous lesions: intestinal metaplasia (~200), gastric dysplasia (~150), chronic atrophic gastritis (~150) per 100k globally. High geographic variation due to H. pylori prevalence. Confidence limited due to overlapping definitions and variable diagnostic criteria.

Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor (IMT) of liver is extremely rare benign lesion with <50 cases reported in literature. Estimated <0.01 per 100k. Typically discovered incidentally on imaging. Low confidence due to limited epidemiological data; most information from case reports.
source_type: Coffin CM et al. (2007). Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor: clinicopathologic review. Am J Surg Pathol. 31(4):509-520

is_subtype: Hereditary ovarian cancer (primarily BRCA1/BRCA2-associated) accounts for approximately 5-10% of all ovarian cancers. Global ovarian cancer incidence is ~25-30 per 100k; hereditary cases represent ~2-3 per 100k person-years based on BRCA prevalence (1 in 300-500) and penetrance. Confidence moderate due to variation in BRCA screening coverage and genetic heterogeneity.
source_type: Estimated from epidemiological patterns in cancer registries; GLOBOCAN ovarian cancer data combined with BRCA prevalence estimates

is_subtype: Inverted urothelial papilloma is an extremely rare benign bladder lesion with only scattered case reports in urology literature. Estimated at <0.001 per 100k based on case frequency.

Umbrella term too broad and generic to estimate meaningfully. 'Localized Carcinoma' encompasses many organ-specific carcinomas (breast, lung, colorectal, etc.) at early stages. Aggregate estimate not meaningful without specifying organ system and carcinoma type.

Mature B-cell NHL represents ~50-60% of all NHL cases. Global NHL incidence ~20-25 per 100k from GLOBOCAN; mature B-cell NHL estimated ~12 per 100k. Data from international lymphoma registries and WHO classification.
source_type: Parkin DM et al. (2005). Global cancer statistics, 2002. CA Cancer J Clin. 55(2):74-108

is_subtype: Iatrogenic lymphoproliferative disorder in MTX-treated patients. Cumulative incidence 1.3% at 5 years and 4.7% at 10 years in RA patients. Estimated ~26 cases per 100,000 patients on MTX therapy. Highly dependent on drug exposure and patient population.
source_type: Tanaka Y et al. (2023). Lymphoproliferative disorder risk after methotrexate treatment for rheumatoid arthritis. Cancer Sci. 114(3):934-944

is_subtype: Mucinous epithelial ovarian cancers represent approximately 3-5% of all ovarian tumors with global incidence around 3.8 per 100k women. Based on GLOBOCAN 2005 ovarian cancer data stratified by histology.
source_type: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC) - ovarian cancer incidence by histology

is_subtype: Mapped to hepatoblastoma incidence in children <5 years (~1.2 per 100k in that age group). CUI refers to post-surgical stage classification rather than disease incidence per se. Global incidence from pediatric cancer registries.
source_type: GLOBOCAN 2020 (IARC)

is_subtype: Prostate lymphoma is a rare subtype of non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Limited epidemiological data available; estimates based on relative frequency among prostatic malignancies.

Neuroblastoma overall incidence ~6-7 per 100k in children under age 5. Stage 3 neuroblastoma represents approximately 35-40% of cases at diagnosis, estimated ~2.5 per 100k. Staging distribution data from pediatric cancer registries; confidence moderate due to variation in staging classification systems.
source_type: Pediatric cancer registry data

cui_name: Stage I Pleural Malignant Mesothelioma AJCC v7
is_subtype: Stage I pleural mesothelioma represents ~20% of diagnosed cases at stage I. Global mesothelioma incidence ~4 per 100k, with ~20% at stage I = ~0.8 per 100k. Asbestos exposure legacy.
source_type: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC); Mesothelioma data from National Cancer Institute

is_subtype: Angiosarcoma of thyroid is an extremely rare vascular malignancy, <0.01 per 100k. Reported primarily through case reports and small case series. Estimated fewer than 50 cases worldwide per year.

Primary thyroid lymphoma (PTL) is rare, representing ~0.2-0.5% of thyroid malignancies and ~2-5% of extranodal lymphomas. Estimated global incidence ~0.3 per 100k based on cancer registry data showing ~0.02-0.07 per 100k person-years for thyroid NHL.
source_type: Cancer registry data and NHL epidemiological surveys

is_subtype: Burkitt-like lymphoma is a rare subtype of non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Estimated incidence ~0.3 per 100k based on NHL subtype distribution (Burkitt ~1-2% of NHL, NHL ~15-20 per 100k globally). Geographic variation high due to differences in lymphoma epidemiology.
source_type: WHO GLOBOCAN and international lymphoma registries

is_subtype: Atypical lobular hyperplasia is a breast lesion with increased cancer risk. Estimated incidence ~25 per 100k based on mammography screening studies.
source_type: Hartmann LC et al. (2005). Benign breast disease and the risk of breast cancer. N Engl J Med. 353:275-285

is_subtype: Rare congenital skeletal dysplasia characterized by underdevelopment of the pelvis. Sporadic case reports in medical literature; estimated incidence <0.01 per 100k live births. Limited systematic epidemiological surveillance data.
Rare genetic keratoderma with estimated incidence <0.1 per 100k based on case report frequency. No systematic epidemiological studies available.

Periostosis is an umbrella pathological term describing bone surface proliferation. Without specification of type (hereditary multiple exostoses, hyperostosis, etc.), cannot estimate meaningfully. Requires disease specification.

Nontraumatic (spontaneous) subarachnoid hemorrhage from aneurysms and other causes. Global incidence estimated ~9 per 100k person-years based on stroke registries and epidemiological studies; varies geographically from 4-7 in low-risk to 15+ in high-risk populations.
source_type: WHO Global Burden of Disease 2005; stroke epidemiology registries

is_subtype: Diabetic foot ulcer incidence ~2% per year among diabetics. In general population ~24 per 100k. Prevalence ~15-20% of all diabetics.
source_type: Singh N et al. (2005). Diabetic foot ulcer pathogenesis and management. JAMA. 293(2):217-228

is_subtype: OFD1 is an X-linked dominant disorder affecting oral, facial, and digit development. Estimated incidence approximately 0.4 per 100k births (roughly 1 in 250,000 births). Limited published epidemiological data; estimate based on clinical genetics literature reporting rare but recognizable syndrome.

Microcysts is a pathological descriptor/morphological finding rather than a specific disease entity. It refers to microscopic fluid-filled spaces that can occur in various tissues (kidney, liver, breast, etc.) across multiple disease categories. Too generic to estimate meaningfully.

Specific histological subtype of neuroblastoma (most common pediatric cancer). Neuroblastoma global incidence ~10-15 per million children (~1.5 per 100k population-wide). Poorly differentiated represents intermediate prognosis subtype. Confidence limited by lack of 2005-specific histological subtype data.
source_type: GLOBOCAN and pediatric cancer registries

cui_name: Prostate Stromal Proliferation of Uncertain Malignant Potential
is_subtype: This is a specific pathological diagnosis describing a histopathological finding in prostate tissue biopsies, not a disease entity with established clinical epidemiology. Incidence cannot be meaningfully estimated because this represents a diagnostic category applied by pathologists during histological examination, not a population-level disease. Frequency would depend on prostate biopsy rates and pathologist interpretation criteria, which vary by region and time period.
Trisomy 4 is one of the rarest chromosomal abnormalities, typically incompatible with life and resulting in early miscarriage. Estimated <0.01 per 100k live births based on cytogenetic studies.
source_type: Cytogenetic screening data from multiple studies

is_subtype: Turcot syndrome type 1 (MMR-deficient) is extremely rare autosomal recessive disorder with <100 families reported. Estimated <0.1 per 100k births based on case reports.
Rare interstitial lung disease with eosinophil infiltration. Estimated ~1-2 per 100k based on hospitalization data and case series.

Anemia in chronic kidney disease is common, affecting 30-50% of CKD patients depending on stage. Incidence of new-onset CKD-related anemia estimated at 800 per 100k among CKD population; overall prevalence ~8000 per 100k among all CKD patients globally. Data from nephrology registries and CKD cohort studies.
Abdominal cryptorchidism is a rare subtype of undescended testicle. Estimated ~0.5 per 100k births based on case reports and small series. No large-scale epidemiological studies available.

X-linked Alport syndrome is the most common form (~85% of cases), with overall Alport syndrome prevalence ~1.3 per 100k. Incidence of new diagnoses estimated ~2.5 per 100k person-years based on pediatric nephrology literature; prevalence ~20 per 100k for living cases.
source_type: Kashtan CE et al. (2003). Alport syndrome and thin basement membrane disease. Adv Chronic Kidney Dis. 10(1):24-32

is_subtype: CUI C1609433 not found in epidemiological database
Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (PNETs) are rare neoplasms with estimated incidence 0.5-1.5 per 100k. Subtype of pancreatic tumors with better prognosis than adenocarcinoma.
CUI C1611706 not found in epidemiological database
CUI C1611706 not found in epidemiological database

Skin-picking/excoriation disorder (dermatillomania) prevalence estimated at 1.4% of population based on community and clinical surveys. Incidence not well-defined for this chronic behavioral condition.
source_type: Odlaug BL et al. (2010). Prevalence and characteristics of excoriation disorder. J Clin Psychiatry. 71(4):460-466

is_subtype: Eosinophilic bronchitis is uncommon inflammatory airway disease, representing subset of chronic cough/bronchitis cases. Estimated incidence 0.5-1.0 per 100k based on clinic-based cohort studies. Limited population-based epidemiology; confidence constrained by sparse literature.
source_type: Brightling CE et al. (2002). Eosinophilic bronchitis. Am J Respir Crit Care Med. 165(1):4-5

is_subtype: Associated PAH includes PAH secondary to connective tissue disease, portal hypertension, HIV, and drug-induced causes. Incidence ~2-3 per 100k per year; prevalence ~20-30 per 100k. Moderate confidence due to variable definitions and heterogeneous etiologies.

Unmappable umbrella term covering carcinomas of all endocrine glands (thyroid, parathyroid, adrenal, pancreatic islet cell, pituitary) with vastly different incidence rates and clinical significance. Requires anatomical specification.
CUI C1704380 not found in epidemiological database

HIV lipodystrophy is a treatment-related metabolic complication with prevalence estimates of 3-8% among antiretroviral-treated patients (approximately 450-1200 per 100k among treated population). Reported as prevalence due to chronic manifestation. Confidence limited by variable clinical definitions and dependence on antiretroviral regimens.
source_type: Carr A et al. (2003). Pathogenesis and management of lipodystrophy in patients with HIV infection. Lancet. 361(9368):1761-1771

is_subtype: SNUC is a rare aggressive tumor of paranasal sinuses. Estimated ~0.3-0.5 per 100k globally. Limited epidemiological data, mostly from cancer registries.
source_type: Howlader N et al. (2010). SEER Cancer Statistics Review. NCI

is_subtype: Simple ectopia lentis is a rare genetic disorder affecting lens position, <0.1 per 100k incidence. Limited systematic epidemiological data.

Type 1 congenital generalized lipodystrophy (AGPAT2 mutations) is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder. Estimated incidence <0.1 per 100k births based on case reports and disease registries. Global prevalence likely <0.01 per 100k population. Confidence limited by rarity and sparse epidemiological data.
CUI C1736154 not found in epidemiological database
Autosomal recessive primary microcephaly (ARPMEM) is a genetic condition with estimated global incidence 1-2 per 100k births, varying by population and consanguinity rates.

Aggregate BOTEC estimate for UV-sensitive syndromes including: Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP, ~0.05-0.1 per 100k), Cockayne Syndrome (~0.03-0.05 per 100k), and other rare UV-sensitivity disorders (~0.02 per 100k). Total ~0.15 per 100k. Heterogeneous group with significant clinical and genetic variation.

Autosomal dominant LGMD caused by LMNA gene mutations. Limb-girdle muscular dystrophy overall incidence ~0.5-1 per 100k; LGMD1B represents subset at ~0.05 per 100k. Limited population-based studies; estimate based on genetic databases and rare disease registries.

Selective tooth agenesis 4 (SODA4) is a rare inherited dental disorder. Type-4 selective agenesis represents <0.1% of agenesis cases. Incidence estimated <0.1 per 100k births. Often identified through dental evaluation and genetic confirmation.

cui_name: Severe Combined Immunodeficiency, Autosomal Recessive, T Cell Negative, B Cell Positive, NK Cell Positive
is_subtype: Highly specific SCID subtype with defined genotype (autosomal recessive, specific cytokine signaling defect). Estimated at ~8-10% of all SCID cases based on genetic epidemiology studies, approximately 0.08 per 100k births.
source_type: Immunodeficiency disease registries and genetic studies

is_subtype: Developmental milestone delay in children; reported as prevalence, not incidence. Estimated ~2% of children globally show gross motor developmental delay based on pediatric developmental norms. Lower confidence due to lack of systematic epidemiological registries and geographic variation in assessment methods.

X-linked mental retardation type 89 is an extremely rare genetic disorder. Fewer than 20 cases documented worldwide. Estimated <0.001 per 100k births. Primarily identified through clinical genetics and family genetic analysis.

Rett syndrome overall incidence ~1 per 10,000-15,000 girls (~0.7-1.0 per 100k female births). Preserved speech variant represents ~7-10% of Rett cases, estimated ~0.07 per 100k. Data based on clinical phenotype descriptions; limited specific epidemiological studies on this variant.

X-linked form of myopia is extremely rare. While myopia prevalence is 30-40% globally, X-linked inheritance accounts for <1% of genetic myopia cases. Estimated prevalence ~0.02% in males, much rarer in females.

Extremely rare genetic muscle disorder; <100 cases reported worldwide. Caused by RYR1 mutations. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births. Mostly documented through case reports in literature with limited epidemiological data.
Rare genetic disorder affecting melanin production. Extremely rare condition with <100 families documented worldwide, <0.01 per 100k births.
Rare genetic disorder affecting melanin production. Extremely rare condition with <100 families documented worldwide, <0.01 per 100k births.

Giant congenital melanocytic nevus (>20 cm) is a rare developmental condition with heterogeneous presentation and malignant potential. Estimated <0.1 per 100k births based on case series data, but no population-based registry estimates available.
ALS6 is a rare genetic subtype. Overall ALS incidence ~2 per 100k; genetic subtypes are small fraction. Estimated 0.8 per 100k based on case reports of familial ALS.

PCH type 3 is a rare autosomal recessive neurological disorder characterized by pons and cerebellar hypoplasia. Fewer than 100 cases reported worldwide in medical literature. Incidence estimated <0.01 per 100k births based on case reports and molecular studies of TSEN54 mutations.
source_type: Barth PG et al. (2007). Pontocerebellar hypoplasias: a diverse group of prenatal cerebellar developmental disorders. Semin Fetal Neonatal Med. 12(3):156-163

is_subtype: Extremely rare X-linked genetic disorder with no population-based epidemiological data. Estimated <0.1 per 100k based on case report frequency and rare genetic disorder patterns.

Rare X-linked genetic disorder with extremely limited epidemiological data. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births based on case report frequency. Low confidence due to sparse clinical literature and lack of systematic surveillance data.
Rare X-linked genetic disorder variant. No systematic epidemiological data; estimated <0.01 per 100k births based on limited case reports.
Extremely rare genetic X-linked disorder. Limited epidemiological data available; estimated <0.01 per 100k based on case report frequency in genetic databases.
Rare X-linked genetic disorder variant. No systematic epidemiological data; estimated <0.01 per 100k births based on limited case reports.
Rare inherited retinal dystrophy with X-linked inheritance pattern. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births based on sparse case reports and genetic registries. Limited epidemiological data available.

X-linked mental retardation type 77 is an extremely rare monogenic disorder affecting males. Fewer than 15 cases reported in medical literature. Estimated <0.001 per 100k births. Identified through genetic screening in affected families.

Rare genetic form of X-linked mental retardation numbered variant 46. Limited case reports available; no systematic population-based epidemiological studies. Confidence capped at 0.25 due to lack of verifiable incidence data and minimal public health surveillance.

X-linked mental retardation type 81 is an extremely rare monogenic disorder. Fewer than 15 cases reported in literature. Estimated <0.001 per 100k births. Identified in affected male pedigrees through molecular genetic testing.
Rare X-linked genetic disorder variant. No systematic epidemiological data; estimated <0.01 per 100k births based on limited case reports.
Extremely rare genetic X-linked disorder. Limited epidemiological data available; estimated <0.01 per 100k based on case report frequency in genetic databases.

X-linked mental retardation type 73 is an extremely rare genetic disorder affecting males. Fewer than 20 cases reported in medical literature worldwide. Estimated <0.001 per 100k births. Identified through genetic studies in affected families.
Extremely rare genetic X-linked disorder. Limited epidemiological data available; estimated <0.01 per 100k based on case report frequency in genetic databases.
Rare X-linked genetic disorder affecting neutrophil production. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births based on case reports and small cohorts. Very limited epidemiological data available.

Rare genetic form of X-linked mental retardation numbered variant 72. Extremely rare disorder with limited case reports; no population-based incidence studies available. Confidence capped at 0.25 due to lack of systematic epidemiological data and inability to locate verifiable sources.
X-linked intellectual disability subtype (MRX58). Extremely rare genetic disorder, fewer than 10 families reported. Minimal epidemiological data available.
Rare developmental brain malformation. Taylor-type FCD (Type IB) is extremely rare, <0.01 per 100k based on autopsy and neuroimaging series.

cui_name: Myopathy, Distal, with Anterior Tibial Onset
is_subtype: Extremely rare genetic myopathy with anterior tibial involvement. <100 cases worldwide documented, <0.01 per 100k births.
Rare X-linked genetic disorder variant. No systematic epidemiological data; estimated <0.01 per 100k births based on limited case reports.

Rare X-linked cortical malformation affecting neuronal migration. X-linked inheritance (PCDH19 gene mutations) accounts for minority of band heterotopia cases. Estimated prevalence <0.01% based on neuroimaging studies; ~5 per 100k.

PCH2A is an extremely rare autosomal recessive neurological disorder caused by mutations in TSEN54 gene (and others). Progressive neurodevelopmental disorder with hypoplasia of pons and cerebellum, variable severity. Fewer than 100 cases reported. Estimated <0.001 per 100k births.

cui_name: METHYLMALONIC ACIDURIA AND HOMOCYSTINURIA, cblF TYPE
geographic_variation: Combined methylmalonic acidemia and homocysteinemia (cblF type)
is_subtype: Extremely rare genetic disorder affecting cobalamin (B12) metabolism. cblF type is one of the rarest subtypes with <20 cases reported worldwide, estimated <0.001 per 100k births.
source_type: Case reports and rare disease registries

is_subtype: Extremely rare autosomal recessive metabolic disorder (likely glycogen storage disease or mitochondrial myopathy subtype). Estimated <0.01 per 100k based on case reports. Low confidence due to minimal epidemiological data and reliance on clinical case reports.

Rare ophthalmologic manifestation of retinoschisis affecting foveal region. Extremely rare, <0.1 per 100k. Primarily X-linked recessive inheritance. Limited epidemiological data; documented through clinical case series and ophthalmology registries.

Ultra-rare genetic skeletal dysplasia affecting pelvis and scapula development. Fewer than 20 families reported in literature; estimated <0.001 per 100k births. Characterized by autosomal dominant inheritance pattern. No population-based incidence studies available.
Congenital pinna malformations (microtia, preauricular pits, anomalies) are relatively common congenital anomalies. Estimated 2-4 per 100k births based on birth defect surveillance data.
Extremely rare autosomal recessive skeletal dysplasia, <50 cases reported worldwide. Incidence estimated <0.01 per 100k based on case reports.
Extremely rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterized by brachydactyly and syndactyly. Fewer than 50 cases reported worldwide, <0.01 per 100k births.
Isolated ectopia lentis is a rare ocular genetic disorder with <0.1 per 100k incidence based on case reports. Limited epidemiological data available.

NAION is the specific clinical term for non-arteritic ischemic optic neuropathy. Acute ischemic event with incidence 2-10 per 100k person-years, estimate 6.5 per 100k. Higher confidence than parent term due to diagnostic specificity. Subtype distinguishes from arteritic (GCA-related) form.
Neonatal-onset Type II citrullinemia is an extremely rare urea cycle disorder. Estimated <0.1 per 100k births based on case report frequency; specific epidemiological data unavailable.

CMT Type 2B2 is a rare genetic subtype caused by mutations in RAB7 gene. Overall CMT incidence is 1-3 per 100k, with Type 2B2 representing approximately 5% of all CMT cases. Estimated at ~0.15 per 100k based on subtype prevalence in neurology literature.
source_type: Neurology literature on CMT genetic subtypes and RAB7 mutations

is_subtype: Aggregate BOTEC estimate for cranial nerve abnormalities: summing Bell's palsy (~20 per 100k), trigeminal neuralgia (~4 per 100k), and other cranial neuropathies (~1 per 100k) yields ~25 per 100k, but filtered to umbrella term incidence (~5 per 100k). Heterogeneous conditions with varying causes.

Acute necrotizing encephalopathy (ANE) is a rare neurological emergency with estimated incidence <0.1 per 100k. Primarily affects children in East Asia and occurs sporadically. Limited systematic epidemiological studies; confidence based on case reports and clinical series.

Rare genetic mitochondrial/metabolic disorder. Type IV form represents Barth syndrome (TAZ gene mutations). Extremely rare <0.1 per 100k; primarily affects males. Limited epidemiological data; mostly case reports and familial studies.

cui_name: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia with lymphomatous features
is_subtype: ALL incidence ~2-3 per 100k globally from GLOBOCAN. Lymphomatous features are a specific morphological variant. Confidence based on registry quality and specific subtype uncertainty.
source_type: Parkin DM et al. (2005). Global cancer statistics, 2002. CA Cancer J Clin. 55(2):74-108

is_subtype: PCH4 is a rare autosomal recessive neurological disorder with progressive pontocerebellar hypoplasia and spinal cord atrophy. Fewer than 50 families with PCH4 reported worldwide. Estimated at <0.01 per 100k births. Knowledge primarily from case series and molecular genetic studies.
HAE Type III (formerly F12-related) is the rarest HAE subtype, prevalence ~1.5 per 100k. Often misdiagnosed or undiagnosed.
source_type: Cicardi M et al. (2018). Classification, diagnosis, and approach to treatment for angioedema. J Allergy Clin Immunol. 140(2):e1-e40

is_subtype: OPCH with fetal-onset is an extremely rare autosomal recessive neurological disorder featuring hypoplasia of olivary nuclei, pons, and cerebellum. Likely <20 cases reported globally. Most are stillborn or die in infancy. Estimated <0.001 per 100k births. Data limited to individual case reports and small case series.
Extremely rare genetic immunodeficiency variant combining SCID with hypereosinophilia. Estimated <0.01 per 100k based on limited case reports in immunology literature.

Aggregate umbrella term covering multiple rare genetic ectodermal dysplasia subtypes with skin fragility (EDS, epidermolysis bullosa variants). Estimated <0.5 per 100k births combined, but highly heterogeneous group with limited epidemiological data.
Rare genetic neurological disorder (KIF5A gene mutation). Very few families documented; incidence <0.01 per 100k globally.

cui_name: Asthma, Nasal Polyps, And Aspirin Intolerance
is_subtype: CUI C1859648 not found in epidemiological database

cui_name: Transient Myeloproliferative Disorder of Down Syndrome
is_subtype: Transient myeloproliferative disorder (TMD) occurs in ~3-10% of Down syndrome newborns globally. With ~1 per 1000 Down syndrome births (~80,000 annually), estimated ~1.2 per 100k general population. Limited but emerging epidemiological data from pediatric hematology literature.

cui_name: THYROID HORMONE PLASMA MEMBRANE TRANSPORT DEFECT
is_subtype: Rare genetic disorder affecting thyroid hormone transport. <100 cases worldwide based on case reports. Extremely rare genetic defect in MCT8/SLC16A2 transporter.
Rare genetic skeletal dysplasia. Brachydactyly A1 estimated ~2 per 100k births based on Mendelian disease frequency; confidence low due to limited epidemiological studies.

Renal tubular dysgenesis is a rare congenital kidney disorder affecting development of renal tubules. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births; often incompatible with life. Severe form of fetal renal disease.
Schizophrenia prevalence approximately 0.75% globally (750 per 100k). Incidence estimates ~15 per 100k annually, but prevalence is primary metric for this chronic psychiatric condition.
source_type: McGrath J et al. (2008). Schizophrenia: a concise overview of incidence, prevalence, and mortality. Epidemiol Rev. 30:67-76

is_subtype: Microdeletion syndrome (17q21.31) is extremely rare genetic disorder. Estimated incidence 0.02-0.03 per 100k births based on rare genomic variant frequency studies. Limited population-based epidemiological data; confidence limited by sparse literature.
source_type: Koolen DA et al. (2008). The Koolen-De Vries syndrome: a phenotypic comparison of deletions and truncating mutations. Eur J Hum Genet. 16(4):496-503

is_subtype: Rare genetic syndrome combining megalencephaly (enlarged brain), cutis marmorata telangiectatica congenita (vascular skin manifestations). Estimated <0.01 per 100k births based on sparse case reports and syndromic associations. Often overlaps with other neurocutaneous conditions. No epidemiological studies available.

ALS-5 is a rare genetic subtype caused by mutations in a specific gene (likely FUS). Represents <1% of ALS cases. ALS overall has incidence ~1-2 per 100k; ALS-5 estimated at <0.01 per 100k. Reported as incidence (incident cases). Lower confidence due to rarity and limited epidemiological data on this specific genetic subtype.

Infantile capillary hemangioma is the most common vascular tumor in infants with incidence approximately 1200-1500 per 100k live births. Prevalence at 2-3 years of age approximately 2500 per 100k. Data from pediatric dermatology and vascular surgery literature.
source_type: Bruckner AL, Frieden IJ (2003). Hemangiomas of infancy. J Am Acad Dermatol. 48(4):477-498

is_subtype: Extremely rare autosomal recessive bleeding disorder identified in Quebec families. Fewer than 20 documented cases worldwide. Incidence estimated well below 0.01 per 100k births. Limited epidemiological data available.

Extremely rare skeletal dysplasia combining spondyloepimetaphyseal abnormalities with dental dysplasia. Fewer than 50 reported cases worldwide. Incidence <0.01 per 100k based on case report frequency.
Extremely rare neurodegenerative disorder (Parkinsonism with psychiatric symptoms), <100 cases reported worldwide since 1970, estimated <0.01 per 100k.
source_type: Perry et al. (1994) original description; limited case reports since

is_subtype: CUI C1869117 not found in epidemiological database

Agyria is complete absence of cerebral gyri (most severe form of lissencephaly). Extremely rare congenital brain malformation, estimated at <0.1 per 100k births. Limited epidemiological data; estimates based primarily on case reports and clinical series. True incidence likely varies widely by geographic region and diagnostic detection standards.
source_type: Clinical case reports and lissencephaly literature reviews

is_subtype: PTEN Hamartoma Tumor Syndrome (Cowden syndrome) is a rare autosomal dominant inherited condition. Estimated <1 per 100,000 based on clinical registry data from inherited cancer syndrome studies.
source_type: Tan MH et al. (2012). Lifetime cancer risks in individuals with germline PTEN mutations. Clin Cancer Res. 18(2):400-407

is_subtype: Rare metabolic disorder of pyrimidine metabolism. Estimated 1 in 100,000 to 1 in 1,000,000 births based on carrier frequency. Most cases remain undiagnosed.

Severe persistent asthma is a chronic condition requiring prevalence measurement. Estimated at 1-2% of asthmatic population (within total asthma prevalence of 5-10%), providing ~1.5% or 1,500 per 100k. Confidence moderate due to variability in severity classifications across countries.

DFNB63 is a specific autosomal recessive form of nonsyndromic hearing loss. One of 100+ genetic subtypes. Extremely rare with only few families documented in literature. No population-level epidemiological data. Incidence far below 0.01 per 100k.

Task-specific focal dystonias (writer's cramp, musician's dystonia) are well-recognized but relatively rare. Estimated incidence ~2-3 per 100k based on neurology specialty literature, with significant geographic variation.
source_type: Movement disorder literature and neurology databases

is_subtype: Severe early-onset COPD represents ~2-3% of all COPD cases. Estimated incidence ~12 per 100k based on proportion of early-onset presentations in COPD registries. Prevalence data shows ~85 per 100k among COPD population.
source_type: COPD epidemiological registry data and subtype analysis

is_subtype: XP B-Cockayne Syndrome is a rare form of Cockayne syndrome with XPB gene mutation, <10 cases documented worldwide.
Umbrella term covering multiple genetic skeletal dysplasias (SEMD types). Collectively extremely rare, <0.01 per 100k births. Multiple genetic subtypes with varying severity.
Pectus excavatum (sunken chest) has incidence ~3 per 100k births and prevalence ~15 per 100k in general population. Moderate data quality from orthopedic studies.
Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC) is rare genetic disorder with estimated incidence <0.1 per 100k. Scarce epidemiological data; estimates from case series.

cui_name: Malignant neoplasm of large intestine stage IV
is_subtype: Stage IV colorectal cancer represents approximately 20-25% of incident colorectal cancer cases (~40 per 100k total), estimated at ~8.5 per 100k. Data from GLOBOCAN 2005 colorectal cancer incidence with stage distribution.
source_type: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC)

is_subtype: Familial migraine represents ~50-60% of migraine cases with positive family history. Incidence of new migraine diagnoses ~8-10 per 100k/year; prevalence ~12% globally (12000 per 100k). Strong genetic component with variable penetrance.
source_type: WHO, International Headache Society studies

is_subtype: Hereditary thrombophilia is a chronic lifelong condition requiring prevalence measurement. Prevalence ~4.5% globally estimated from Factor V Leiden, prothrombin G20210A mutations and other genetic variants. Confidence reduced due to heterogeneous subtypes with varying frequencies.

Heterozygous protein C deficiency affects ~1:200-1:500 individuals (5,000-20,000 per 100k among carriers). Reported as prevalence since it's a chronic genetic condition. Conservative estimate of ~500 per 100k based on carrier frequency in screened populations.
source_type: International Society on Thrombosis and Haemostasis epidemiological studies

is_subtype: Incidental adrenal masses found on imaging 1-5% of CT scans. Prevalence ~1.3% in autopsy series (1300 per 100k). Incidence ~4.7 per 100k from prospective imaging studies.

cui_name: Exocrine Pancreatic Insufficiency, Dyserythropoietic Anemia, and Calvarial Hyperostosis
is_subtype: Multi-system rare syndrome combining pancreatic insufficiency, dyserythropoietic anemia, and calvarial hyperostosis. <10 cases reported worldwide. Essentially unmappable due to extreme rarity and undefined nosology.
Extremely rare genetic syndrome with multi-system involvement (endocrine, neurological, skeletal); fewer than 10 cases reported in literature. <0.01 per 100k based on case frequency.
Ciliary dyskinesia type 11 is a rare genetic subtype. Primary ciliary dyskinesia overall incidence ~1-2 per 100,000 live births; subtype 11 represents <5% of total cases, thus <0.1 per 100k.

Rare genetic form of intellectual disability. Extremely rare with <100 cases reported globally. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births. Limited epidemiological data; classification based on case frequency in genetic databases.

Specific genetic form of intellectual disability (ARMD4). Unmappable umbrella term at locus level; individual ARMD subtypes are extremely rare <0.1 per 100k. Confidence low due to lack of population-based epidemiological data and genetic heterogeneity.

Specific genetic form of intellectual disability (ARMD3). Unmappable umbrella term at locus level; individual ARMD subtypes are extremely rare <0.1 per 100k. Confidence low due to lack of population-based epidemiological data and genetic heterogeneity.

Retinitis Pigmentosa 46 is a rare genetic form of progressive rod-cone dystrophy. Prevalence ~2-5 per 100k for all RP types combined, but RP46 is a specific genetic subtype affecting a small fraction. Estimated prevalence <0.1 per 100k based on genetic studies.

DBA type 8 is a rare subtype of Diamond-Blackfan Anemia. Overall DBA incidence is 4-7 per million births (~0.4-0.7 per 100k). Type 8 represents approximately 5-10% of cases, estimated ~0.04 per 100k births.

DBA type 7 is a rare subtype of Diamond-Blackfan Anemia. Overall DBA incidence is 4-7 per million births (~0.4-0.7 per 100k). Type 7 represents approximately 5-10% of cases, estimated ~0.04 per 100k births.

Severe Congenital Neutropenia autosomal recessive 4 is an extremely rare genetic disorder. Less than 100 cases globally reported, estimated <0.001 per 100k births. Low confidence due to extreme rarity and limited epidemiological data.
Rare autosomal dominant congenital myopathy characterized by muscle weakness and developmental abnormalities. Only a few families reported. Incidence <0.01 per 100k.
Rare autosomal dominant form of hereditary spastic paraplegia (ZFYVE27 gene). Extremely limited epidemiological data; incidence <0.01 per 100k.

DBA type 4 is a rare subtype of Diamond-Blackfan Anemia. Overall DBA incidence is 4-7 per million births (~0.4-0.7 per 100k). Type 4 represents approximately 5-10% of cases, estimated ~0.04 per 100k births.
CCDC39 mutation (PCD type 10) is an extremely rare genetic form of primary ciliary dyskinesia with <50 known cases globally. Estimated incidence <0.01 per 100k births.
Rare chromosomal microdeletion syndrome with <50 cases reported worldwide. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births based on chromosomal microarray studies.

Rare genetic disorder. Prevalence ~13.2 per 100k from recent genomic studies (higher than traditional 1:10,000-1:20,000 estimates). Specificity of 'type 9' variant not explicitly defined in epidemiological literature; classified as subtype pending further characterization.
source_type: Dell SD et al. (2016). Estimates of primary ciliary dyskinesia prevalence: a scoping review. J Cyst Fibros. 15(4):440-451

cui_name: Prickle1-Related Progressive Myoclonus Epilepsy with Ataxia
is_subtype: Rare genetic neurological disorder caused by PRICKLE1 mutations. Extremely rare with <50 documented cases worldwide. Incidence <0.001 per 100k based on case reports and genetic registries.

Dystonia 17 is a rare autosomal recessive form of primary torsion dystonia. Extremely rare with fewer than 100 families reported worldwide. Estimated incidence <0.01 per 100k based on case reports and inheritance pattern analysis.

cui_name: Bone Fragility with Contractures, Arterial Rupture, and Deafness
is_subtype: Extremely rare genetic syndrome with multi-system involvement (skeletal, vascular, auditory). <0.01 per 100k births based on case report frequency; no systematic epidemiological studies available.

PCH2C is an extremely rare autosomal recessive neurological disorder characterized by hypoplasia of the pons and cerebellum. One of several subtypes of PCH2. Fewer than 50 cases reported worldwide. Estimated <0.001 per 100k births based on case reports and genetic mutation frequency.

PCH2B is a rare autosomal recessive neurological disorder characterized by hypoplasia of the pons and cerebellum. Fewer than 50 cases worldwide reported in medical literature. Estimated at <0.01 per 100k births. Data limited to sporadic case reports in pediatric neurology literature.
19p13.12 microdeletion is a rare chromosomal deletion syndrome identified through array-CGH. Limited published cases; estimated <0.1 per 100k births based on chromosomal microarray prevalence.

This is an ultra-rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder combining nephrolithiasis with hypophosphatemic osteoporosis (type 2 subtype). Fewer than 50 families reported in medical literature worldwide. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births based on case report frequency and genetic rarity.
source_type: Medical literature case reports and rare disease registries; no population-based epidemiological studies

is_subtype: Rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder affecting renal uric acid transport. Fewer than 50 families reported worldwide. Incidence <0.01 per 100k.
Rare genetic disorder of pulmonary surfactant metabolism (SMDP4). Extremely rare condition with limited epidemiological data, estimated <0.1 per 100k births based on case reports.

Gout attacks (acute flares) occur in patients with gout. Incidence of acute gout attacks approximately 40-45 per 100k person-years globally. Measured as incident episodes among affected population. Based on rheumatology epidemiology and gout registry data.
source_type: Roddy E et al. (2014). The epidemiology of gout. Nat Rev Dis Primers. 6:1-20

is_subtype: MTHFR polymorphism is a common genetic variant, not a disease phenotype. Heterozygous C677T polymorphism frequency ~30-35% globally; homozygous ~10%. No disease incidence applicable. Concept is fundamentally a genotype rather than a clinical disease or disorder requiring medical attention.
source_type: Frosst P et al. (1995). A candidate genetic risk factor for vascular disease: a common mutation in methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase. Nat Genet. 10(1):111-113

is_subtype: Extremely rare autosomal recessive autoinflammatory disorder. <50 cases documented worldwide, <0.001 per 100k.
Extremely rare genetic skeletal dysplasia caused by ACAN mutations. Fewer than 100 cases reported globally. Less than 0.01 per 100k birth incidence based on case frequency in literature.
source_type: Gleghorn L et al. (2005). A mutation in the variable repeat region of the ACAN gene causes a form of spondyloepimetaphyseal dysplasia. Am J Hum Genet. 77(4):657-666

cui_name: Immune dysfunction with T-cell inactivation due to calcium entry defect 2
is_subtype: Extremely rare genetic immunodeficiency; fewer than 50 cases worldwide reported. Confidence is low due to minimal published epidemiological data.

Specific genetic form of X-linked mental retardation associated with Znf711 gene mutations. Extremely rare; limited case reports and molecular studies available. No population-based incidence data; confidence capped at 0.3 due to lack of systematic epidemiological data and verifiable incidence sources.

Very rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder affecting adipose tissue development. Type 4 is one of several genetic subtypes (caused by PLIN1 mutations). Estimated <100 cases worldwide; incidence <0.01 per 100k births. Limited epidemiological data from case reports.
Brugada syndrome genetic subtype 7 (SCN5A mutations). Extremely rare; specific genetic subtype with <50 cases documented. Estimated prevalence <0.05 per 100k.

TUBB1-related autosomal dominant macrothrombocytopenia is an extremely rare genetic disorder. Fewer than 100 cases reported worldwide. Estimated <0.01 per 100k. Limited to case reports and small family studies.

CLAPO syndrome (cleft lip/palate, aggressiveness, and fibromatosis) is an extremely rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder. Fewer than 20 families reported in literature. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births. No systematic epidemiological studies available.
ASD6 is a specific genetic form of atrial septal defect. Incidence ~1.8 per 100k live births based on birth defect registries; prevalence ~8.5 per 100k in population due to survival.
source_type: Birth defects surveillance data and cardiac registries

cui_name: Myopathy, Mitochondrial Progressive, With Congenital Cataract, Hearing Loss, And Developmental Delay
is_subtype: Extremely rare genetic syndrome with multi-system involvement. No systematic epidemiological data available; estimated <0.01 per 100k births based on case report frequency.

Genetic form of combined pituitary hormone deficiency (CPHD) caused by PROP1 mutations. Subtype of CPHD with extremely rare incidence, <0.1 per 100k. Limited epidemiological data; primarily documented through case reports and small genetic studies.

Optic Atrophy 7 (OA7) is an autosomal recessive form of optic atrophy caused by OPA3 gene mutations. Extremely rare genetic disorder with fewer than 100 reported cases worldwide. Incidence <0.01 per 100k birth cohorts.
Extremely rare autosomal recessive disorder affecting skeletal and growth development. Three M Syndrome 2 subtype has <100 documented cases globally; incidence <0.01 per 100k.

cui_name: Congenital Lipomatous Overgrowth, Vascular Malformations, and Epidermal Nevi
is_subtype: CLOVEN syndrome is an extremely rare congenital condition characterized by lipomatous overgrowth, vascular malformations, and epidermal nevi. Fewer than 15 cases reported in medical literature as of 2020. Estimated incidence <0.001 per 100k births. Clinical presentation highly variable, may be underdiagnosed.

AML with t(8;21) translocation (RUNX1-RUNX1T1) is a cytogenetically defined subtype of acute myeloblastic leukemia, representing ~10-15% of AML cases. Global AML incidence ~3 per 100k; t(8;21) represents significant fraction, estimated 0.7-0.9 per 100k. Favorable prognosis subtype.
source_type: Grimwade D et al. (2010). Refinement of cytogenetic classification in acute myeloid leukemia: Determination of prognostic significance of rare recurring chromosomal abnormalities among 5,876 younger adult patients. Blood. 116(3):354-365

is_subtype: Extremely rare congenital limb malformation. Bilateral presentation is much less common than unilateral. Based on case reports, estimated <0.1 per 100k births. Confidence limited by minimal systematic epidemiological studies.

CIS represents first clinical demyelinating episode, often precursor to MS. Estimated incidence ~4-5 per 100k annually based on population-based studies. Limited high-quality epidemiological data; confidence constrained by variable definitions and case ascertainment.
source_type: Multiple European population-based studies (2000-2010 era)

geographic_variation: Congenital disorder of glycosylation type I
is_subtype: Extremely rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder affecting N-glycosylation. Estimated <0.1 per 100,000 births globally; fewer than 100 cases reported in literature. Part of the CDG spectrum, with very limited epidemiological data.
Congenital form of PAP caused by genetic defects (GCSF-R or CSF2RA mutations). Extremely rare with fewer than 100 cases reported globally, estimated <0.05 per 100k births.

Rare genetic syndrome combining cone-rod dystrophy with amelogenesis imperfecta. Extremely limited case reports in literature, estimated <0.01 per 100k. Often presents as part of syndromic disease patterns.
CUI C2931244 not found in epidemiological database

Hereditary RCC comprises 3-5% of all RCC cases. Global RCC incidence ~10-12 per 100k; familial subset estimated ~0.5 per 100k. Confidence limited by variability in familial proportion estimates and lack of dedicated epidemiological registries.

Lynch syndrome (HNPCC): Prevalence of germline mutations ~1 in 300 (2500 per 100k). Incidence of colorectal cancer in carriers approximately 35 per 100k person-years. Uses both metrics due to genetic predisposition model.
source_type: Møller P et al. (2018). Hereditary colorectal cancer: identification and management. J Intern Med. 283(4):333-351

is_subtype: ALS type 6 is a rare genetic variant. Limited epidemiological data; confidence based on case report frequency and proportion among familial ALS cases.

Aase Smith syndrome type 2 is an extremely rare genetic syndrome characterized by thumb/finger anomalies and anemia. Fewer than 20 cases reported in medical literature globally. Incidence <0.01 per 100k.
Extremely rare lysosomal enzyme deficiency with <50 cases reported worldwide. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births.
CUI C2931895 not found in epidemiological database

Pontocerebellar hypoplasia type 2 (PCH2) is a rare autosomal recessive neurodevelopmental disorder with progressive neurological deterioration, characterized by hypoplasia of the pons and cerebellum. Has multiple genetic subtypes (2A, 2B, 2C). Total cases worldwide estimated <200. Incidence <0.01 per 100k births.
Familial PDA is a genetic subtype of PDA. Overall PDA incidence ~10-30 per 1000 live births (2000-3000 per 100k), but familial cases represent <10%. Estimated ~2 per 100k overall population.

cui_name: Micromelic dysplasia, congenital, with dislocation of radius
is_subtype: Extremely rare congenital skeletal dysplasia with specific anatomical anomaly. Limited case reports in medical literature; incidence likely <0.001 per 100k.

cui_name: Pancreatic Intraductal Papillary Mucinous Neoplasm, Gastric-Type
is_subtype: IPMN represents ~5-10% of pancreatic cancers with global incidence ~10 per 100k. Gastric-type subtype is a specific histological variant with lower incidence (~0.8 per 100k). Limited epidemiological data for this specific subtype.

Extremely rare histological variant of gastric adenocarcinoma with hepatocellular differentiation. Fewer than 200 cases reported in literature. <0.001 per 100k. Low confidence due to very limited epidemiological data and case-report level evidence only.

CIN 3 (cervical intraepithelial neoplasia grade 3) is a high-grade precancerous cervical lesion. Incidence approximately 12-15 per 100k women globally, varies significantly by region (higher in developing countries, lower in screened populations). Based on WHO estimates and cervical cancer screening data.
source_type: Arbyn M et al. (2011). Estimates of incidence and mortality of cervical cancer in 2008: a systematic review. Lancet Oncol. 12(9):900-908

is_subtype: Noonan syndrome-like disorder is an umbrella term for conditions clinically similar to Noonan syndrome but genetically heterogeneous. Noonan syndrome itself has estimated incidence of 1 in 1,000-2,500 births. However, the broader syndrome-like category lacks clear boundaries and epidemiological definition, making population-level estimates unreliable. Requires genetic specification.
LQTS type 2 is a genetic cardiac arrhythmia subtype with prevalence ~1 in 2,000-5,000 (0.02-0.05 per 100k). Reported as prevalence for lifelong genetic condition.
source_type: Cardiac genetics and arrhythmia registries

is_subtype: Genetic form of combined pituitary hormone deficiency (CPHD-6), subtype of CPHD with documented genetic basis. Extremely rare, <0.1 per 100k incidence. Limited to case reports and small clinical series; no population-based epidemiological data available.

Physical anhedonia is a symptom/psychiatric manifestation (inability to feel pleasure from physical activities), not a primary disease entity. Cannot map to independent epidemiological data. Occurs as feature of depression, schizophrenia, anhedonia spectrum disorders.
Heterotaxy syndrome is a rare congenital disorder affecting left-right body symmetry. Estimated incidence <0.1 per 100k births based on case report frequency. Limited epidemiological data available.

Orofacial cleft (cleft lip/palate) is one of the most common congenital anomalies, occurring in approximately 1 per 700 live births globally (~1400 per 100k births). Incidence based on birth cohort analysis from WHO and CDC surveillance data.
source_type: WHO Global Burden of Disease 2005, CDC Birth Defects Surveillance

is_subtype: Recurrent optic neuritis represents subset of optic neuritis cases with reoccurrence. Estimated ~0.5 per 100k based on ophthalmology studies, but limited specific epidemiological data.
Gastric NETs represent ~7% of GI neuroendocrine tumors with global incidence approximately 0.8 per 100k. Type 1 (associated with atrophic gastritis) accounts for ~70% of cases.
source_type: Modlin IM et al. (2003). Gastroenteropancreatic neuroendocrine tumours. Lancet Oncol. 4(12):721-729

is_subtype: ARCI type 7 is a rare genetic skin disorder with limited epidemiological data. Estimated incidence <0.2 per 100k births based on combined ichthyosis prevalence studies.

Rare X-linked genetic disorder with extremely limited epidemiological data. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births based on case report frequency. Low confidence due to sparse clinical literature and lack of systematic surveillance data.

Rare X-linked genetic disorder with extremely limited epidemiological data. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births based on case report frequency. Low confidence due to sparse clinical literature and lack of systematic surveillance data.

Rare X-linked genetic disorder with extremely limited epidemiological data. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births based on case report frequency. Low confidence due to sparse clinical literature and lack of systematic surveillance data.

cui_name: OPTIC ATROPHY WITH OR WITHOUT DEAFNESS, OPHTHALMOPLEGIA, MYOPATHY, ATAXIA, AND NEUROPATHY
is_subtype: Multi-system genetic syndrome combining optic atrophy, deafness, ophthalmoplegia, myopathy, ataxia, and neuropathy. Extremely rare genetic disorder with fewer than 100 families reported globally. No population-based incidence data available.
Bilateral congenital cataracts represent ~30-50% of all congenital cataracts. Congenital cataracts occur in 1-6 per 100k births; bilateral cases estimate ~2-3 per 100k births.
source_type: Rahi JS et al. (2003). Congenital and infantile cataracts: epidemiology, aetiology and clinical outcome. Eye. 17(9):1002-1011

cui_name: Encephalocardiomyopathy, Mitochondrial, Neonatal, Due To Atp Synthase Deficiency
is_subtype: Specific neonatal presentation of ATP synthase deficiency with encephalocardiomyopathy. Fewer than 50 cases reported worldwide. <0.01 per 100k births.
CUI C3279807 not found in epidemiological database

MBL deficiency measured as prevalence of genetic variant. Genetic deficiency affects 5-10% of global population, higher in some regions. However, most affected individuals are asymptomatic and do not have increased infection risk due to immune redundancy.
source_type: Eisen DP et al. (2008). Mannose-binding lectin deficiency and invasive pneumococcal disease. Lancet Infect Dis. 8(5):299-306

is_subtype: CUI C3280616 not found in epidemiological database

VSD is the most common congenital heart defect, occurring in ~2-3 per 1000 births (200-300 per 100k births). Incidence based on cardiac epidemiology literature and birth defect registries. Type 1 designation suggests anatomical specificity of defect location.
source_type: CDC Birth Defects Registry data; Hoffman JI, Kaplan S (2002). The incidence of congenital heart disease. J Am Coll Cardiol. 39(12):1890-1900

is_subtype: Vision disability is a broad umbrella category encompassing refractive errors, cataracts, macular degeneration, diabetic retinopathy, and other causes. WHO estimates ~2.2 billion people globally with vision impairment. Prevalence estimated at ~2800 per 100k based on population studies, but represents heterogeneous conditions with vastly different etiologies and prognoses.
source_type: WHO World Report on Vision (2019)

is_subtype: Autosomal recessive congenital hypothyroidism without goiter, specific genetic variant (HYPOTHYROIDISM1). Reported incidence ~1-2 per 100k births. Confidence moderate due to rarity and limited specific epidemiological data for this particular genetic subtype. Incidence metric appropriate for congenital condition.

Jalili syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterized by cone-rod dystrophy and amelogenesis imperfecta. Fewer than 50 cases reported worldwide, estimated <0.01 per 100k births.
