Frontonasal dysplasia type 1 is a rare genetic craniofacial disorder, <0.01 per 100k births. Autosomal dominant condition with high variability. Fewer than 100 cases reported in literature.

Rare compound genetic condition combining dysmyelinating leukodystrophy with spastic paraparesis. Estimated <0.01 per 100k based on case report frequency. Very limited epidemiological data available; confidence reflects rare disease with few documented cases.

Nonmedullary thyroid carcinoma (papillary, follicular, anaplastic, lymphoma) shows global incidence approximately 6.5 per 100k from GLOBOCAN 2005 data. Predominantly papillary type (80%+). Varies geographically with higher rates in areas with adequate iodine intake.
source_type: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC), WHO Cancer Incidence Database

is_subtype: X-linked acute leukemia is an extremely rare subtype. Estimated incidence ~0.8 per 100k based on case report frequency, but limited systematic epidemiological data available.
Diabetic cardiomyopathy incidence estimated at 8.5 per 100k in diabetic population (8% annual risk). Limited to those with diabetes. Confidence moderate due to variable case definitions.
source_type: Jia G et al. (2018). Endothelial dysfunction, inflammation, and atherosclerosis in diabetic cardiomyopathy. Front Physiol. 9:564

is_subtype: Hereditary essential tremor 4 (ET4) is a rare genetic subtype, prevalence ~4% of general population for essential tremor overall, but ET4 represents small fraction (<1% of ET cases).

UV-Sensitive Syndrome 2 (USS2) is an extremely rare genetic disorder characterized by sun sensitivity. Limited epidemiological data; fewer than 50 reported cases globally. Incidence <0.01 per 100k, primarily identified through genetic research rather than population surveillance.
Porokeratosis type 7 (PORK7) is a rare genetic keratoderma. Part of heterogeneous porokeratosis family with <1 case per 100k. Limited epidemiological data; multiple genetic subtypes exist.

Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (central hypogonadism) is a specific subtype with estimated incidence 2-3 per 100k. Prevalence around 8 per 100k based on hormone replacement therapy usage patterns. Limited epidemiological data available.
source_type: Dandona P, Rosenberg MT. (2010). A practical guide to male hypogonadism in the primary care setting. Int J Clin Pract. 64(6):682-696

is_subtype: Peroxisomal biogenesis disorder 11A is ultra-rare autosomal recessive metabolic disease, part of Zellweger spectrum (PEX mutations). Incidence <0.01 per 100k births. PBD11A specifically represents small fraction of Zellweger cases; only few families reported worldwide. Very limited epidemiological data.
Castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC) develops in ~10-15% of hormone-treated prostate cancer patients. Estimated ~3 per 100k men globally.

Hirschsprung disease (aganglionosis of intestinal tract) incidence approximately 1-2 per 100k live births. Rare congenital anomaly with male predominance (4:1). Estimate of ~2 per 100k represents typical epidemiological data from pediatric registries.
Rare genetic immunodeficiency. Autosomal recessive CGD (AR-CGD) accounts for <5% of CGD cases. Total CGD incidence ~1-2 per million births, AR-CGD significantly rarer.

Congenital heart defects occur in ~6-8 per 1000 births globally (~600-800 per 100k live births). Using conservative 600 per 100k based on WHO/CDC prevalence data. Broad category but well-defined by birth defect registries.
source_type: WHO Global Burden of Disease, congenital heart defect prevalence estimates

is_subtype: Ultra-rare genetic neurodegeneration with fatty acid metabolism defects. Fewer than 50 confirmed cases globally reported in literature, estimated <0.001 per 100k births. Low confidence due to lack of systematic epidemiological data.

Proliferative verrucous oral leukoplakia (PVOL) is a rare, aggressive oral cancer precursor. Estimated incidence <0.2 per 100k based on case series and limited epidemiological data. Diagnosis requires specific histopathological criteria, limiting epidemiological tracking.

cui_name: Distal Hereditary Motor Neuropathy, Type II
is_subtype: dHMN type II is a specific genetic form of distal hereditary motor neuropathy. Incidence ~0.15 per 100k; prevalence ~0.8 per 100k based on neurology specialty registries and case reports.

RP66 is a specific genetic subtype of retinitis pigmentosa caused by mutations in a defined gene. Retinitis pigmentosa overall affects 1 in 3000-7000 people globally. RP66 represents a small fraction of RP cases. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births for this specific subtype. Limited epidemiological data specific to RP66.
CUI C3805211 not found in epidemiological database
Extremely rare genetic X-linked disorder. Limited epidemiological data available; estimated <0.01 per 100k based on case report frequency in genetic databases.
Rare X-linked genetic disorder variant. No systematic epidemiological data; estimated <0.01 per 100k births based on limited case reports.

Immunodeficiency 8 (likely DOCK8 deficiency or similar specific genetic disorder) is an extremely rare primary immunodeficiency. Estimated <0.1 per 100k globally based on case report frequency and genetic rarity. No comprehensive epidemiological registry data available.

CMT2R is a specific autosomal recessive axonal subtype of CMT disease caused by LMNA or other gene mutations. Overall CMT prevalence ~1 per 100k, with type 2 (axonal) forms comprising ~20% of cases. CMT2R appears to be a rare subtype with limited published epidemiological data. Estimate based on proportion of CMT2 disease and clinical series data.
source_type: Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease Association; peer-reviewed CMT subtype literature

is_subtype: Multiple fibroadenomas (≥2 distinct fibroadenomas) represent a subset of breast fibroadenoma cases. While fibroadenomas themselves occur in ~10-25% of women, multiple concurrent fibroadenomas are less common. Estimated at ~0.5 per 100k based on limited literature.

L-ferritin deficiency is not a recognized disease entity in medical literature. Ferritin (H and L chains) regulation affects iron metabolism, but 'L-ferritin deficiency' as a clinical condition is not established.

Aggregate BOTEC estimate summing major pediatric respiratory infections: acute respiratory infections (7000-8000), pneumonia (3000-4000), acute bronchitis (1500), influenza (500-1000) = approximately 12,000 per 100k children annually. High incidence in pediatric populations but significant geographic and seasonal variation.
Symptom or behavioral descriptor rather than a disease entity. Not mappable to incidence rates; appears across multiple psychiatric and neurological conditions.
CUI C3825570 not found in epidemiological database

Umbrella term too heterogeneous and undefined. Includes benign (hemangiomas, fibromas) and malignant (lung cancer, mesothelioma, mediastinal tumors, thymic tumors, chest wall sarcomas) neoplasms with vastly different incidence rates, clinical significance, and epidemiology. Cannot provide meaningful aggregate estimate without specification of tumor type and anatomy.

Transient hypothyroidism occurs in 1-3% of premature infants; estimated incidence ~15 per 100k preterm births. Neonatal thyroid screening data shows variable reported rates depending on prematurity severity and screening cutoff values.
source_type: Neonatal thyroid screening registries

is_subtype: Anemia in malignant neoplastic disease is a secondary complication/manifestation of cancer, not a primary disease entity. Prevalence varies dramatically depending on cancer type, stage, and treatment. Cannot be meaningfully estimated as independent epidemiological entity without specification of primary cancer type.

Oval fat body is a histopathological finding (lipid droplets in urine visible under polarized microscopy), not a disease entity. It occurs secondary to nephrotic syndrome, glomerulonephritis, and other kidney disorders. Cannot be meaningfully mapped to disease incidence without specifying the underlying renal pathology.

Enterovirus 71 is endemic in Asia-Pacific region, causing hand-foot-mouth disease and neurological complications. Global incidence estimated ~2.5 per 100k (primarily from epidemic years in endemic regions). Geographic variation is high, with significant clustering in Southeast/East Asia.
Specific subtype of spinal tumors limited to intraspinal location. Estimated ~2-2.5 per 100k based on pathology registries, lower than total spinal neoplasms due to anatomical specificity.
X-linked intellectual disability subtype (MRX49). Extremely rare genetic disorder, fewer than 20 families reported worldwide. Limited epidemiological data available.
NSF associated with gadolinium contrast agents, estimated <0.5 per 100k among MRI patients. Limited epidemiological data from case reports.
Rare genetic developmental disorder characterized by microcephaly and limb abnormalities. Estimated <0.1 per 100k births based on isolated case reports.
Extremely rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder; <50 cases reported worldwide. Incidence likely <0.001 per 100k.
Polymorphic nonnuclear congenital cataract is a specific morphological subtype. Incidence ~0.5 per 100k births; prevalence ~2.2 per 100k based on ophthalmologic and genetic registry data.
source_type: Ophthalmologic epidemiology databases and congenital anomaly registries

is_subtype: Extremely rare genetic X-linked disorder. Limited epidemiological data available; estimated <0.01 per 100k based on case report frequency in genetic databases.
Extremely rare genetic syndrome with multi-system involvement. Estimated <0.05 per 100k births based on case reports in medical literature.
AMAN is a subtype of GBS with different pathophysiology (axonal vs demyelinating). Represents 5-15% of GBS cases in developed countries, higher in Asia. Limited direct incidence data.

Extremely rare genetic subtype (familial AF type 15). <0.01 per 100k based on case reports of rare monogenic variants. Confidence limited by lack of systematic population-based epidemiological studies.
Type ID hyperlipoproteinemia (familial chylomicronemia) is a rare lipid disorder. Estimated incidence ~2-3 per 100k based on genetic screening studies, though clinical diagnosis rates are lower.
Centronuclear myopathy (myotubular myopathy), rare genetic myopathy estimated <1 per 100k. Limited epidemiological data.
Immunodeficiency 26 is a rare primary immunodeficiency disorder. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births based on case report frequency, but no systematic epidemiological registry data available.
Rare genetic disorder combining palmoplantar keratoderma with woolly hair phenotype. Extremely rare condition, likely <0.01 per 100k with limited published epidemiological data.

Subcoronal hypospadias is the most common anatomical variant of hypospadias, accounting for approximately 50-60% of all cases. Based on global hypospadias incidence of ~3.5 per 1000 male births (3500 per 100k), subcoronal variant estimated at ~10.5 per 100k births.
source_type: International birth defect surveillance and urological epidemiology data

is_subtype: Bicoronal synostosis is bilateral coronal suture fusion, a distinct craniosynostosis subtype. Often associated with Crouzon syndrome. Accounts for ~15-20% of craniosynostosis cases, estimated ~0.5 per 100k live births. Limited epidemiological data.
Pathological descriptive term, not a disease entity. Umbrella term too vague and generic to estimate meaningfully.

Unicoronal synostosis is a specific subtype of craniosynostosis. Overall craniosynostosis incidence ~0.8-1 per 2000 births (~4-5 per 100k live births). Unicoronal accounts for ~10% of cases, estimated ~0.4-0.5 per 100k. Confidence limited by sparse literature.
Rare congenital mandibular anomaly, <0.05 per 100k births based on case reports and craniofacial registry data.

Late-onset muscular dystrophy encompasses several types with onset in adulthood (Limb-girdle MD, Oculopharyngeal MD, Facioscapulohumeral MD). Estimated combined incidence ~0.5 per 100k in adult populations. Limited population-based data; estimates based on specialist clinic populations and rare disease registries.

Chorioretinal atrophy is a descriptor of retinal structural change with multiple etiologies (geographic atrophy in AMD, myopic atrophy, post-inflammatory, dystrophic). Prevalence estimated ~50 per 100k based on retinal disease prevalence studies, but confidence is low due to heterogeneous causes and lack of unified incidence data.

Rare fibrous condition with estimated incidence 0.1-1.3 per million person-years from case series and retrospective studies. Using conservative estimate of ~0.08 per 100k based on limited epidemiological literature.
source_type: Case series data from European and North American registries

is_subtype: SPG51 is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder affecting motor neurons. <0.01 per 100k based on limited case reports; no systematic epidemiological data available.

Hormone refractory breast cancer represents approximately 10-15% of breast cancer cases. Global breast cancer incidence is ~50 per 100k (women), so hormone-refractory subset estimated at ~5-6 per 100k. Data from oncology literature on endocrine resistance rates.
source_type: Oncology literature on hormone receptor status and endocrine resistance

is_subtype: Grade II chondrosarcoma is intermediate-grade malignant cartilage tumor. Global chondrosarcoma incidence ~0.3-0.4 per 100k; Grade II represents approximately 40-50% of cases, estimated at 0.15 per 100k. Based on bone tumor registries and epidemiological estimates.
source_type: Giuffrida AY et al. (2009). Chondrosarcoma: composition, demographics, and outcomes of a North American cohort. J Bone Joint Surg Am. 91(5):1063-1072

is_subtype: CRMO is a rare chronic inflammatory bone disease predominantly affecting children. Estimated incidence 0.5-1 per 1,000,000 births (~0.08 per 100k person-years). Often under-diagnosed due to rarity and diagnostic complexity.
source_type: Jansson A et al. (2007). Chronic recurrent multifocal osteomyelitis in children: a nation-wide survey. J Rheumatol. 34(5):1122-1126

is_subtype: Oligodontia (congenital absence of 6+ teeth, excluding third molars) affects ~1.5% of children globally based on dental epidemiological surveys. Prevalence in pediatric populations ~15 per 100k.
source_type: WHO Global Oral Health Survey data and dental epidemiology studies

is_subtype: Glutaric acidemia type III is an extremely rare organic acidemia with autosomal recessive inheritance. Only a handful of confirmed cases in medical literature. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births. Characterized by elevated urinary glutarate.
Familial LCAT deficiency is an extremely rare autosomal recessive lipid disorder; <50 cases reported worldwide in literature. Estimated <0.001 per 100k births.

Familial hyperekplexia (startle disease) is a rare genetic neurological disorder with excessive startle response and muscle rigidity. Estimated <0.1 per 100k based on case reports. Autosomal dominant inheritance, primary mutations in GLRA1, GLRB genes. Limited epidemiological literature.

Specific autosomal recessive subtype of hereditary sideroblastic anemia, represents minority of genetic forms. Estimated <0.1 per 100k births based on rare disease literature. Limited epidemiological data available.

PMD-like disorders represent a heterogeneous group of rare leukodystrophies with various genetic etiologies (GJA12, SURF1, TUBB4A mutations). Estimated incidence <0.1 per 100k with <500 confirmed cases globally. Difficult to diagnose, many cases likely missed.

Atypical presentation of Werner syndrome (adult progeria), a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by WRN mutations. Atypical variants are even rarer than classic presentation. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births globally, with <200 cases reported worldwide.

cui_name: Autosomal dominant optic atrophy plus syndrome
is_subtype: Rare genetic disorder, fewer than 100 cases worldwide, <0.01 per 100k births. OPA plus variant with additional neurological manifestations.

Perinatal arterial ischemic stroke (PAIS) occurs in newborns and infants. Estimated incidence approximately 2 per 100k live births (1:2,500 to 1:5,000 infants). Limited epidemiological data available; estimates based on neonatal stroke registries and cohort studies.
source_type: Neonatal stroke registry data and pediatric stroke cohort studies

is_subtype: Hormone-sensitive (androgen-responsive) prostate cancer represents approximately 70-75% of newly diagnosed prostate cancers. Global prostate cancer incidence is ~60 per 100k (GLOBOCAN estimates). Hormone-sensitive subset estimated at ~45 per 100k. Based on cancer registry data and androgen-sensitivity classification frequency in prostate cancer cohorts.

cui_name: Hyperinsulinism due to uncoupling protein 2 deficiency
is_subtype: UCP2-deficiency-related hyperinsulinism is an extremely rare genetic metabolic disorder. UCP2 mutations account for <5% of PHHI cases. Estimated incidence <0.01 per 100k, with fewer than 50 cases reported globally.

Autosomal dominant macrothrombocytopenia encompasses several genetic subtypes with rare occurrence globally. Estimated <0.05 per 100k based on hematologic genetics literature. No large population-based epidemiological studies available.
Extremely rare chromosomal microdeletion with <100 reported cases globally. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births based on cytogenetic case reports. Low confidence due to limited epidemiological data.
Benign concentric annular macular dystrophy is a rare retinal disorder with minimal published epidemiological data. Very few case reports available, suggesting incidence <0.001 per 100k.

Leber plus disease is an extremely rare genetic disorder combining Leber hereditary optic neuropathy with systemic manifestations. Estimated <0.01 per 100k based on case report frequency. Very limited epidemiological data available.

Congenital analbuminemia is an extremely rare genetic disorder with absence of serum albumin. Only approximately 100 cases reported worldwide; estimated <0.01 per 100k. Based on case report frequency only.

Osteomalacia incidence ~3.5 per 100k from sparse epidemiological data; prevalence higher at ~2.5% (2500 per 100k) in populations with limited sun exposure and poor dietary vitamin D. Metabolism-related bone disease with significant geographic variation. Data primarily from regional studies and case reports.
Extremely rare progressive neurological disorder with childhood onset. <100 cases reported worldwide. No systematic epidemiological surveys; estimates based on case report frequency <0.01 per 100k.

Nutritional deficiency more common in low-income countries with limited dietary diversity. Global incidence of clinical pellagra (severe form) ~12 per 100k; mild deficiency prevalence estimated ~80 per 100k in endemic regions. Geographic variation substantial; limited global surveillance data.

Hyperleukocytosis is a complication of acute leukemia, primarily in pediatric ALL/AML. Estimated ~0.5 per 100k based on acute leukemia incidence (2-3 per 100k) with hyperleukocytosis occurring in 5-30% of cases.

Aggregate BOTEC estimate for end-stage lung diseases summing major categories: advanced COPD (~300 per 100k), end-stage interstitial lung disease (~120 per 100k), cystic fibrosis exacerbations (~20 per 100k), terminal lung cancer (~250 per 100k), advanced pulmonary hypertension (~80 per 100k), post-COVID lung fibrosis (~80 per 100k). Heterogeneous conditions with overlapping progression.

Neutrophil extracellular trap (NET) formation is a cellular/molecular process, not a disease diagnosis. NETs are involved in innate immunity and are associated with numerous inflammatory and autoimmune conditions, but NET formation itself is not a mappable epidemiological entity. Requires specification of underlying disease condition.

Hypertensive end-organ damage describes secondary complications of uncontrolled hypertension (renal dysfunction, left ventricular hypertrophy, retinopathy). This is a manifestation state rather than primary disease. Prevalence estimated at ~8.5% of global population with chronic hypertension complications, derived from hypertension prevalence data.

Umbrella term too broad to estimate meaningfully. Includes all solid malignancies (breast, lung, colorectal, prostate, ovarian, pancreatic, etc.) with vastly different epidemiology. Would require specification of organ system and histological type.
Gingival SCC is a specific subtype of oral cancer. Global oral cancer incidence ~3-5 per 100k, gingival SCC represents ~5-10% of oral cancers. Estimated ~0.3 per 100k based on anatomic distribution.

Not a mappable disease entity. 'Reduced amygdala volume' is a neuroanatomical finding or symptom descriptor associated with various psychiatric and neurological conditions (depression, PTSD, autism spectrum disorder), not a disease itself. Cannot estimate incidence without disease specification.

XMRV (Xenotropic Murine Leukemia Virus-Related Virus) was initially proposed as a pathogen associated with prostate cancer and ME/CFS. However, subsequent large-scale studies (2010-2012) failed to confirm XMRV detection in patient samples, and the virus's human pathogenicity remains unestablished. No reliable epidemiological data exists. Unmappable due to unproven human infectivity.

Omodysplasia is an extremely rare autosomal recessive skeletal dysplasia with fewer than 20 cases reported worldwide. No systematic epidemiological data; estimated <0.01 per 100k based on limited case literature.

cui_name: Acute myeloid leukemia with t(8;16)(p11;p13) translocation
is_subtype: AML with t(8;16) translocation is a rare cytogenetic subtype of AML, typically monocytic differentiation (FAB M5). Represents ~1-2% of all AML cases. Global AML incidence ~3-4 per 100k (adults); t(8;16) subset incidence approximately 0.15 per 100k. WHO/FISH classified genetic subtype with distinct clinical/prognostic features.
source_type: Grimwade D et al. (2010). Refinement of cytogenetic classification in acute myeloid leukemia. Blood. 116(3):354-365

cui_name: Autosomal dominant primary hypomagnesemia with hypocalciuria
is_subtype: Extremely rare autosomal dominant genetic disorder of magnesium reabsorption in kidney. Caused by mutations in FXYD2/CASR genes. Fewer than 50 cases reported globally in medical literature, estimated <0.001 per 100k births.

cui_name: Mucinous tubular and spindle cell carcinoma
is_subtype: Mucinous tubular and spindle cell carcinoma (MTSCC) is a rare renal cell carcinoma subtype, comprising <1% of RCC cases. Estimated incidence <0.05 per 100k based on case series and pathology reviews. Limited epidemiological data from population-based registries.
source_type: Srigley JR et al. (2013). WHO/ISUP classification of renal neoplasia. Am J Surg Pathol. 37(10):1463-1484

is_subtype: CUI C4521481 not found in epidemiological database

Unable to map this CUI to a well-defined disease entity. HELIX SYNDROME either represents an insufficiently specific/defined condition, a very recently described syndrome with limited epidemiological data, or may be a proprietary/institutional terminology not in standard medical nomenclature. Cannot estimate incidence/prevalence without clearer clinical definition.

Anaplastic astrocytoma (WHO Grade III glioma) incidence ~0.5-0.7 per 100k globally from GLOBOCAN/brain tumor registries. Recurrent cases represent subset (estimated 60-70% of initial cases eventually recur). Using incidence for incident cases, though 'recurrent' designation adds prognostic specificity. Metric appropriate for incident tumors.
source_type: Ostrom QT et al. (2014). CBTRUS statistical report: primary brain and central nervous system tumors diagnosed in the United States in 2007-2011. Neuro Oncol. 16(Suppl 4):iv1-63

is_subtype: Atypical Spitz nevus is a specific histological variant of benign melanocytic lesion, rarely tracked as distinct epidemiological entity. Estimated ~0.8 per 100k based on dermatopathology practice patterns. Confidence limited by lack of systematic population-based incidence data.

cui_name: Cutaneous Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Head and Neck
is_subtype: Cutaneous SCC of head/neck region represents majority of cutaneous SCC cases. Global incidence ~18 per 100k, highest in fair-skinned, UV-exposed populations.
source_type: Alam M et al. (2001). SCC of skin and variants. J Am Acad Dermatol. 45(6):949-971

cui_name: Stage IV Colon Cancer AJCC v8
is_subtype: Stage IV colon cancer (AJCC v8 classification) represents approximately 18-20% of incident colon cancers (~40 per 100k total), estimated at ~7.2 per 100k. Similar to C2217040 but specific to colon (excludes rectum). Based on GLOBOCAN 2005 colon cancer data with AJCC stage distribution.
source_type: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC)

is_subtype: Mucinous adenocarcinoma represents approximately 20-25% of gastric cancers. Global gastric cancer incidence ~10-15 per 100k; estimating mucinous subtype at ~2.5 per 100k. Limited literature specifically on mucinous gastric histology.

CRD7 is a rare inherited retinal dystrophy with autosomal recessive inheritance. Progressive vision loss affecting both cone and rod photoreceptors. Global incidence estimated 0.2-0.5 per 100k person-years based on inherited retinal disease registries. Point estimate 0.3 per 100k.
source_type: Koenekoop RK. (2005). Gene families for retinal dystrophies. Ophthalmic Genet. 26(1):3-15

cui_name: Acute Lung Injury/Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS)
is_subtype: ARDS is an acute critical care syndrome with incidence estimates of 40-80 per 100k globally. Using 58.5 per 100k as global average from epidemiological studies. Acute condition measured by new case incidence annually.
source_type: Rubenfeld GD et al. (2005). Incidence and outcomes of acute lung injury. N Engl J Med. 353(16):1685-1693

is_subtype: Highly specific subtype of bronchitis with bacterial etiology and protracted/persistent course. This is a narrowly-defined condition with minimal epidemiological literature. Incidence data unavailable; would constitute a small subset of acute bronchitis cases.

Robinow syndrome autosomal dominant type 1 is an extremely rare genetic disorder (mesomelic dwarfism with facial and genital abnormalities). Estimated <0.1 per 100k based on limited case reports. Fewer than 100 families documented worldwide.
Rare genetic movement disorder; specific PNKD1 subtype with <100 families documented worldwide. Estimated prevalence ~0.1 per 100k based on genetic registries.
Deuteranopia (green cone deficiency) accounts for approximately 50% of red-green color blindness cases. Prevalence ~1% in males (1000/100k), 0.01% in females (10/100k); weighted average ~2500/100k.
source_type: Neitz J & Neitz M. (2011). The genetics of normal and defective color vision. J Ophthalmol. 2011:321639

is_subtype: Protanopia (red-blindness) is an X-linked recessive color vision deficiency affecting ~1% of males (~10,000 per 100k in males) and <0.01% of females. Global prevalence estimate ~0.8% of population (~8,000 per 100k). Population prevalence data from color vision epidemiology studies.
source_type: Hunt DM et al. (1995). Molecular genetics of human color vision. Science. 267:1979-1981

is_subtype: Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS/AIDP) incidence from epidemiological studies ranges 0.6-2.4 per 100k, with global average ~1.5 per 100k. Data quality variable by country.

cui_name: Stage I Ovarian Cancer AJCC v8
is_subtype: Stage I ovarian cancer represents early-stage disease (~15% of cases). GLOBOCAN 2005 reports ovarian cancer at ~10 per 100k globally. Stage-specific data not directly available; estimate 1.5 per 100k for Stage I from proportional analysis.
source_type: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC), with proportional stage breakdown from cancer registries

is_subtype: Rare congenital eye defect affecting uvea and retina. Coloboma incidence ~1 per 10,000 live births; uveoretinal is a specific subtype. Estimated ~0.3 per 100k based on case frequency in pediatric populations.

cui_name: Neurodevelopmental disorder with hypotonia, neuropathy, and deafness
is_subtype: This is a rare multisystem genetic disorder combining neurodevelopmental impairment, hypotonia, peripheral neuropathy, and sensorineural deafness. Appears to be a recently characterized genetic condition with <100 cases reported worldwide. Virtually no population-based epidemiological data available; knowledge limited to case reports in medical literature.

Pulmonary artery intimal sarcoma (PAIS) is an extremely rare malignant tumor arising from the intima of the pulmonary artery. Estimated <0.01 per 100k based on case reports and small case series. Very limited epidemiological data; only dozens of cases reported in medical literature.

cui_name: Advanced Lung Non-Squamous Non-Small Cell Carcinoma
is_subtype: Specific subtype of lung cancer: NSCLC (~80% of lung cancer) × non-squamous histology (~60% of NSCLC) × advanced stage (III-IV, ~40-50% at diagnosis). Global lung cancer incidence ~25 per 100k; advanced non-squamous NSCLC estimated ~6.5 per 100k based on GLOBOCAN and cancer registry data.
source_type: GLOBOCAN 2020 (International Agency for Research on Cancer)

is_subtype: DFNB57 is one of >100 autosomal recessive deafness loci. Extremely rare genetic form; non-syndromic AR deafness overall ~0.5 per 100k live births. DFNB57 specifically represents <1% of AR deafness cases.

Atypical scrapie is a TSE (transmissible spongiform encephalopathy) primarily affecting sheep and goats. Human transmission is not established. Incidence in human population is effectively zero or unmappable, with extremely rare occupational exposure cases only.
source_type: EFSA (European Food Safety Authority). Scientific Opinion on the epidemiology of atypical scrapie in sheep and goats. EFSA J. 2014;12(2):3568

is_subtype: Nonmedullary thyroid cancer (papillary and follicular) accounts for ~95% of thyroid cancers. Global incidence ~8.5 per 100k with significant geographic variation.
source_type: La Vecchia C et al. (2015). Thyroid cancer epidemiology. Best Pract Res Clin Endocrinol Metab. 29(6):981-1002

is_subtype: Neuroblastoma overall incidence ~10 per 100k in children <5 years. Resectable (Stage 1-2) cases comprise approximately 40-50% of all neuroblastoma cases, estimated at ~8.5 per 100k. Staging data available from international cancer registries.
source_type: International cancer registries and neuroblastoma surveillance data

is_subtype: Castration-sensitive prostate carcinoma represents ~90% of prostate cancers globally. Prostate cancer incidence ~35-40 per 100k from cancer registries; confidence reflects CSPC as major subtype.
source_type: GLOBOCAN prostate cancer estimates

is_subtype: BRCA1-associated hereditary breast and ovarian cancer accounts for approximately 5-10% of all breast cancers and a higher proportion of ovarian cancers. Estimated incidence ~8.5 per 100k combining both breast and ovarian cancers in BRCA1 carriers. Based on population prevalence of BRCA1 mutations and lifetime risk estimates.
source_type: Peto J et al. (2000). The contribution of inherited gene mutations to cancer in Europe. Eur J Cancer. 36(18):2352-2382

is_subtype: Obstructive sleep apnea characterized by apneas (breathing cessation) and hypopneas (reduced breathing). Reported as prevalence rather than incidence (chronic condition). Global prevalence estimated at 9% of adults (~9,000 per 100k). Wide variation by age, sex, and population. Conservative estimate based on multiple population studies.
source_type: Heinzer R et al. (2015). Prevalence of sleep-disordered breathing in the general population: the HypnoLaus study. Eur Respir J. 45(3):670-679

is_subtype: Pancreatic cancer overall incidence ~11 per 100k (GLOBOCAN 2005). Locally advanced stage represents approximately 30% of cases at diagnosis, suggesting ~3.2 per 100k incidence. Confidence moderate due to stage-specific estimation.
source_type: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC)

is_subtype: Extremely rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder presenting in infancy with parkinsonism and dystonia. No systematic epidemiological studies; estimated <0.01 per 100k based on case report frequency.

cui_name: MITOCHONDRIAL COMPLEX I DEFICIENCY, NUCLEAR TYPE 16
is_subtype: Mitochondrial Complex I Deficiency, Nuclear Type 16 is an extremely rare genetic metabolic disorder. Fewer than 50 cases reported worldwide. Estimated <0.01 per 100,000 births. Limited epidemiological data; primarily identified through genetic testing.
CUI C4748786 not found in epidemiological database

Extremely rare genetic mitochondrial disorder caused by FASTKD2 mutations. Fewer than 50 cases documented worldwide in medical literature. Estimated <0.001 per 100k births. Identified primarily through case reports and genetic sequencing studies in affected families.
Familial cervical artery dissection is a rare genetic subtype of cervical artery dissection, estimated at <0.1 per 100k based on case reports. Limited epidemiological data available.
Isolated form of ATP synthase deficiency without associated complex presentations. Very rare; estimated <0.05 per 100k births based on pediatric mitochondrial disease case series.
